In February 1962, the family moved to the United States, settling in [[Pasadena, California]].<ref name="vimeo"/> Both Eddie and his older brother, [[Alex van Halen|Alex]], are [[Naturalization|naturalized]] U.S. citizens.<ref>{{cite news|last=Christopher|first=Michael|date=February 6, 2015|title=Rock Music Menu: Eddie Van Halen set for Smithsonian talk|url=http://www.delcotimes.com/article/DC/20150206/NEWS/150209755|newspaper=Delaware County Daily Times|location=Upper Darby Township, PA|access-date=February 13, 2016}}</ref> The brothers learned to play the piano as children starting at the age of six.<ref>{{cite web|title=Q&A: Eddie Van Halen|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/eddie-van-halen-19980416|accessdate=2015-10-06}}</ref><ref name="All Music Guide - Eddie Van Halen">[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p133912|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic.org]; accessed December 1, 2017.</ref>
They commuted from Pasadena to [[San Pedro, Los Angeles|San Pedro]] to study with an elderly man, [[:lt:Stasys Kalvaitis|Stasys (Stanley) Kalvaitis]]<ref name="van-halen.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.van-halen.com/video/vh-interviews|title=VH Interviews|publisher=van-halen.com|accessdate=2014-07-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140723175023/http://www.van-halen.com/video/vh-interviews|archivedate=July 23, 2014}}</ref> who taught them classical piano. Although they hated the commute, they continued as their mother would discipline them if they refused to go.
Van Halen revealed in an interview that he was never able to read music. Instead, he learned from watching and listening. During recitals of [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]] or Mozart, he would improvise. From 1964 through 1967, he won first place in the annual piano competition held at [[Long Beach City College]].<ref name="van-halen.com"/> Afterward, the judges would comment that he had an interesting interpretation of the classical piece. Van Halen's view was, "What? I thought I was playing it correctly!" However, according to one interview, playing the piano did not prove to be challenging or interesting to him.<ref name="obrecht">{{cite web|url=http://jasobrecht.com/eddie-van-halen-complete-1978-interviews|title=Transcript of interview with Jas Obrecht|website=jasobrecht.com|accessdate=June 1, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111022020333/http://jasobrecht.com/eddie-van-halen-complete-1978-interviews/|archivedate=October 22, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Consequently, while Alex began playing the guitar, Eddie bought a drum kit and began practicing for hours every day.
After Eddie heard Alex's performance of [[The Surfaris]]' [[drum solo]] in the song ''[[Wipe Out (Surfaris song)|Wipe Out]]'', he decided to switch instruments and began learning how to play the electric guitar. According to Eddie, as a teen, he would often practice while walking around at home with his guitar strapped on or sitting in his room for hours with the door locked.<ref name="lick-library">{{cite web|title=Eddie Van Halen Birthday Special|url=http://www.licklibrary.com/newsletters/issue114-uk.html|work=Lick Library|accessdate=October 26, 2013|date=January 2010|issue=114|quote=[...] However, when Alex started to then learn to play drums, overtaking Eddie's own abilities, the younger of the two switched to guitar instantly becoming attached to it – locking himself away in his bedroom as a teen to practice, and walking around the house with his guitar strapped on yet unplugged. [...]}}</ref><ref name="guitar-lessons">{{cite web|title=Eddie Van Halen Biography, Videos & Pictures|url=http://www.guitarlessons.com/guitarists/rock/eddie-van-halen|work=GuitarLessons.com|accessdate=October 26, 2013|quote=...]In an interview with Guitar World, Eddie explained his practice ethic during his teenage years. 'I used to sit on the edge of my bed with a six-pack of Schlitz Malt talls. My brother would go out at 7 p.m. to party and get laid, and when he'd come back at 3 a.m., I would still be sitting in the same place, playing guitar. I did that for years – I still do that.'[...]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029195320/http://www.guitarlessons.com/guitarists/rock/eddie-van-halen|archivedate=October 29, 2013}}</ref>
Eddie Van Halen acknowledged the importance of supergroup [[Cream (band)|Cream]]'s "[[I'm So Glad]]" on ''[[Goodbye (Cream album)|Goodbye Cream]]'' to be "mind-blowing".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aolradio.slacker.com|title=AOL Radio Stations|first=Slacker|last=Inc|website=AOL Radio|accessdate=June 1, 2017}}</ref> He once claimed that he had learned almost all of [[Eric Clapton]]'s solos in the band Cream "...note for note." "I've always said Eric Clapton was my main influence," Van Halen said, "but [[Jimmy Page]] was actually more the way I am, in a reckless-abandon kind of way."<ref>[http://www.classicvanhalen.com/bios_evh.shtml Classicvanhalen.com], Guitar World Interview (February 1990).</ref>
Eddie and Alex formed their first band with three other boys, calling themselves ''The Broken Combs'', performing at lunchtime at Hamilton Elementary School in Pasadena, where Eddie was in the fourth grade. Eddie would later say that this was when he first felt the desire to become a professional musician.<ref>{{YouTube|UOTidtqG-Ko|Van Halen 2012 Interview}}</ref>
==Formation of Van Halen== {{more citations needed|section|date=December 2017}} {{Main article|Van Halen}} [[File:Eddie Van Halan - 77 in New Haven.jpg|thumb|upright|Van Halen in [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven]], 1978.]] In 1972, Van Halen formed another band, originally called "Genesis". The name was changed to "Mammoth" when Van Halen became aware of the English [[progressive rock]] band [[Genesis (band)|of the same name]].<ref>{{cite web|title=15 Years On: Eddie Van Halen Interview Revisted|url=http://www.vhnd.com/2013/07/08/15-years-on-eddie-van-halen-interview-revisted|website=Van Halen News Desk|accessdate=December 5, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130711064101/http://www.vhnd.com/2013/07/08/15-years-on-eddie-van-halen-interview-revisted/|archivedate=July 11, 2013|date=July 8, 2013|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Mammoth consisted of Van Halen on guitar and lead vocals, his brother Alex on drums and bass guitarist [[Mark Stone (musician)|Mark Stone]]. Mammoth had no [[Public address|P.A. system]] of their own, so they rented one from [[David Lee Roth]],<ref name="guitarcom">{{Cite news|last=Obrecht|first=Jas|date=July 23, 1978|title=A Legend is Born: Eddie Van Halen's First Interview|periodical=Guitar.com|url=//www.guitarplayer.com/archive/artists/vanhalen.shtml|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000819115344/http://www.guitarplayer.com/archive/artists/vanhalen.shtml|archivedate=August 19, 2000}}</ref> a service for which he charged by the night. Van Halen became frustrated with singing lead vocals,<ref name="guitarcom"/> and decided they could save money by adding Roth to the band.<ref name="guitarcom"/> Soon after, [[Michael Anthony (musician)|Michael Anthony]] replaced Stone on the bass guitar. The band opted to change its name because Roth suggested that the last name of the two brothers "sounded cool".{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
At one point, the band considered using the name "Rat Salade", after the [[Black Sabbath]] [[Rat Salad|song of the same name]], before settling on "Van Halen".<ref name="Roll 2001">Rolling Stone Encyclopedia of Rock and Roll, 3rd Edition, 2001, Rolling Stone Press, U.S. pg.1028</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Van Halen facts, information, pictures|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/people/literature-and-arts/music-popular-and-jazz-biographies/van-halen#C|website=encyclopedia.com|accessdate=December 5, 2016}}</ref> The band originally began playing [[Cover version|cover material]], ranging from [[Pop music|pop]] to [[disco]].<ref name="Roll 2001"/>
In 1976, band supporter [[Rodney Bingenheimer]] invited [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]] bass guitarist [[Gene Simmons]] to check out a Van Halen show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whiskyagogo.com/articles/770104.html|title=WHISKY ARTICLES|publisher=Whisky A-Go-Go|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}</ref> Impressed, Simmons soon produced a Van Halen [[Demo (music)|demo tape]] with recording beginning at the [[The Village (studio)|Village Recorder]] studios in Los Angeles and finishing with [[Overdubbing|overdubs]] at the [[Electric Lady Studios]] in New York.<ref>Everybody Wants Some: The Van Halen Saga by Ian Christie, {{ISBN|978-0-470-03910-6}}</ref>
Looking to strike a [[recording contract]], Simmons shopped the demo tape around, but found no success. In May 1977 at the [[Starwood (nightclub)|Starwood]], Van Halen was spotted by record producer [[Ted Templeman]]. Like Simmons, Templeman was impressed and quickly convinced [[Warner Bros. Records]] executive [[Mo Ostin]] to sign the band, and they accepted 24 hours later. Their [[Van Halen (album)|self-titled debut album]] was recorded in mid-September to early October 1977, and was released on February 10, 1978.
===David Lee Roth Era=== Van Halen released a total of six albums with vocalist David Lee Roth: ''[[Van Halen (album)|Van Halen]]'' (1978), ''[[Van Halen II]]'' (1979), ''[[Women and Children First]]'' (1980), ''[[Fair Warning (Van Halen album)|Fair Warning]]'' (1981), ''[[Diver Down]]'' (1982), and ''[[1984 (Van Halen album)|1984]]'' (1984).
In the early 1980s, the band began having increasing trouble working together as a cohesive unit. According to Gene Simmons' book ''Kiss and Make-Up'', Eddie Van Halen approached Simmons in 1982 about possibly joining Kiss to replace [[Ace Frehley]], chiefly because of his personality conflicts with Roth. Simmons and Alex Van Halen persuaded Eddie to remain in Van Halen, while Kiss replaced Frehley with [[Vinnie Vincent]].
Shortly afterwards, Van Halen released the album ''[[1984 (Van Halen album)|1984]]'', from which the single "[[Jump (Van Halen song)|Jump]]", was their first and only #1 single on the [[''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. Other singles released from the album performed well, particularly "[[Hot for Teacher]]", the video for which featured a scantily dressed model playing the part of a female elementary school teacher and young actors portraying the band members as children. The album peaked at #2 on the [[Billboard charts]], behind only [[Michael Jackson]]'s ''[[Thriller (Michael Jackson album)|Thriller]]''.
Jimmy Page said at the time, "For my money, Van Halen was the first significant new kid on the block. Very dazzling."<ref>Zlozower, Neil. ''Van Halen: A visual history: 1978–1984'' (2008)<!-- publisher, ISSN/ISBN, page(s) needed --></ref>
In 1982, Van Halen was invited by producer [[Quincy Jones]] to contribute the guitar solo for Michael Jackson's single, "[[Beat It]]", but reportedly declined any payment for the recording, deeming a credit on the album sufficient.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/11/30/showbiz/music/van-halen-jackson-thriller/index.html|title=Eddie Van Halen deconstructs his collaboration on 'Beat It'|first=By Denise Quan|last=CNN|publisher=CNN|date=November 30, 2012}}</ref>
===Sammy Hagar Era=== [[File:Eddie Van Halen (1993).jpg|thumb|Van Halen at the [[45th Primetime Emmy Awards|45th Emmy Awards]], 1993.]] With the arrival of former [[Montrose (band)|Montrose]] singer [[Sammy Hagar]] in July 1985, the band's sound changed somewhat to adapt to the strengths of the new vocalist. Eddie Van Halen's keyboard playing became more prominent, as heard in songs such as "[[Dreams (Van Halen song)|Dreams]]" and "[[Love Walks In]]". Hagar appeared on four studio albums with the band, ''[[5150 (album)|5150]]'' (1986), ''[[OU812]]'' (1988), ''[[For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge]]'' (1991), and ''[[Balance (Van Halen album)|Balance]]'' (1995), as well as one live album, ''[[Live: Right Here, Right Now]] ''(1993).
During Hagar's time with the band, some fans informally referred to the band as "Van Hagar" to distinguish it from the David Lee Roth lineup. With Hagar, all four studio releases reached No. 1 on the [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] charts. ''For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge'' was awarded the [[34th Annual Grammy Awards|1992]] [[Grammy Award]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Hard Rock Performance|Best Hard Rock Performance with Vocal]]. The live album ''Live: Right Here, Right Now'' peaked at No. 5.
===Gary Cherone Era=== Following Hagar's departure, the group briefly reunited with original singer David Lee Roth and released ''[[Best Of – Volume I (Van Halen album)|Best Of – Volume I]]'', a greatest-hits package, in October 1996. Two new songs were recorded for the album, "[[Me Wise Magic]]"—which reached No. 1 on the [[mainstream rock]] chart as a single—and "[[Can't Get This Stuff No More]]". However, previous disagreements resurfaced and the reunion did not last. Roth left in September 1996 after the [[MTV Video Music Award]]s.
The band auditioned many prospective replacements for Hagar, finally settling on [[Gary Cherone]], former frontman of Boston hard rock band [[Extreme (band)|Extreme]]. Cherone predicted that the new lineup would last "10 years"; however, the ''[[Van Halen III]]'' (1998) album was poorly received. The band completed a world tour with their new single "[[Without You (Van Halen song)|Without You]]" and returned to the studio to start on a second album. However, Cherone soon after departed amicably and, without a lead singer, Van Halen went on hiatus.
===Reunion with Hagar and Roth=== [[File:David Lee Roth and Eddie Van Halen 2007-11-10.jpg|thumb|Van Halen (right) with [[David Lee Roth]], November 2007.]] In 2004, Van Halen returned with Hagar as their lead singer. A greatest hits package, ''[[The Best of Both Worlds (Van Halen album)|The Best of Both Worlds]]'', was released to coincide with the band's reunion tour. The album included three new tracks recorded with Hagar, "Up For Breakfast", "It's About Time", and "Learning to See". The band toured the United States, visiting 80 cities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.van-halen.com/newsite/road.html|title=2004 tour listing on van-halen.com|website=van-halen.com|accessdate=June 1, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061219081921/http://www.van-halen.com/newsite/road.html|archivedate=December 19, 2006}}</ref>
On February 2, 2007, it was officially announced on the band's website that David Lee Roth would rejoin Van Halen for their summer tour.<ref>[http://van-halen.com/newsite/pressrelease.html Van-halen.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403221011/http://van-halen.com/newsite/pressrelease.html|date=April 3, 2007}}, Van Halen Press Release</ref> Excitement over the tour waned when, on February 20, 2007, reports surfaced that the tour was indefinitely postponed. A previously planned compilation of Roth-era Van Halen hits was shelved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pollstar.com/news/viewnews.pl?NewsID=7687|title=Link To Us|publisher=Pollstar|accessdate=December 1, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080630000651/http://www.pollstar.com/news/viewnews.pl?NewsID=7687|archivedate=June 30, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
After six months and a stint in rehabilitation for Eddie, the band confirmed on August 13, 2007, at a press conference in [[Los Angeles]], they would do a [[Van Halen 2007-2008 Tour|tour]] with Roth from late 2007 into 2008 across North America, with worldwide touring and a new album to follow.<ref name="cnn">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/SHOWBIZ/Music/08/13/vanhalen.reut/index.html?iref=mpstoryview|title=Van Halen, with Roth, to begin reunion tour|accessdate=August 13, 2007|work=CNN|date=August 14, 2007}}</ref> Persistent rumors had long indicated the Van Halen brothers were in talks with Roth to rejoin the band for a tour and/or new material. Van Halen's then 15-year-old son [[Wolfgang Van Halen|Wolfgang]] was to play bass on the tour, replacing Michael Anthony.
===2000s=== Van Halen [[Van Halen 2007–2008 North American Tour|toured]] the U.S. and Canada from September 2007 through summer 2008. The band released their twelfth studio album, ''[[A Different Kind of Truth]]'', on February 7, 2012, their first album in 14 years and their first album with Roth since ''1984''. <ref>{{cite web|title=A Different Kind of Truth|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/a-different-kind-of-truth-mw0002295183}}</ref>
==Style and influence== Van Halen's approach to the guitar involves several distinctive components. His use of two-handed [[tapping]], natural and artificial [[harmonics]], [[vibrato]], and [[tremolo]] picking, combined with his rhythmic sensibility and melodic approach, have influenced an entire generation of guitarists. The [[Instrumental rock|instrumental]] "Eruption" was voted No. 2 in ''[[Guitar World]]'' magazine's readers poll of the 100 Greatest Guitar Solos.<ref>[http://guitar.about.com/library/bl100greatest.htm About.com], 100 Greatest Guitar Solos; accessed December 1, 2017.</ref><ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5937559/the_100_greatest_guitarists_of_all_time Rollingstone.com], 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time</ref> Despite his massive success, Van Halen has never fully learned to read music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esquire.com/the-side/music/eddie-van-halen-interview-2012-8147775|title=Eddie Van Halen Interview – Esquire Eddie Van Halen Interview |publisher=Esquire|date=April 17, 2012|accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref>
===Tapping=== {{Main article|Tapping}} The 1978 instrumental "[[Eruption (instrumental)|Eruption]]" by Van Halen showcased a solo technique called [[tapping]], using both left and right hands on the guitar neck. Although Van Halen popularized tapping, he did not invent the tapping technique which had been used infrequently by various guitarists in blues and rock in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s. {{fact|date=July 2018}}
[[George Lynch (musician)|George Lynch]] said in an interview that he and Van Halen saw [[Harvey Mandel]] tap at the Starwood in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://themetalden.com/index.php?p=198|title=Interview: George Lynch|publisher=themetalden.com|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}</ref> Van Halen's accounts of how he came across the tapping technique vary. In one interview with ''[[Guitar World]]'', he said:{{quote|I think I got the idea of tapping watching Jimmy Page do his "[[Heartbreaker (Led Zeppelin song)|Heartbreaker]]" solo back in 1971. He was doing a pull-off to an open string, and I thought wait a minute, open string ... pull off. I can do that, but what if I use my finger as the nut and move it around? I just kind of took it and ran with it.<ref>[http://www.guitarworld.com/article/van_halen_vh1 Van Halen: VH1] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110115053118/http://www.guitarworld.com/article/van_halen_vh1|date=January 15, 2011}}, ''[[Guitar World]]''; accessed December 1, 2017.</ref>}}
Van Halen also employs [[Tap harmonic|tapping harmonics]]. He holds the pick between his thumb and middle finger, which leaves his index finger free for tapping, and also makes for easy transitions between picking and tapping.
Van Halen holds a patent for a flip-out support device that attaches to the rear of the electric guitar.<ref>{{US patent|4656917| U.S. Patent No. 4,656,917}}, ''Musical instrument support'', April 14, 1987, Edward L. Van Halen, inventor.</ref> This device enables the user to play the guitar in a manner similar to the piano by orienting the face of the guitar upward instead of forward.<ref>{{cite web|title=Musical instrument support|url=https://patents.google.com/patent/US4656917A/en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Celebrity Invention: Eddie Van Halen's Guitar Support System|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2011/02/celebrity-invention-eddie-van-halens-guitar-support-system/70770/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=United States Patent Van Halen|url=http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect2=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=/netahtml/PTO/search-bool.html&r=1&f=G&l=50&d=PALL&RefSrch=yes&Query=PN/4656917}}</ref>
==Pickup selection== Van Halen has used a variety of pickups including Gibson PAF's, 1970s Mighty Mites, [[DiMarzio]]s and Ibanez Super 70s. He was using Mighty Mite pickups in 1977 club photos, just prior to the recording of the first Van Halen album. Mighty Mite pickups were [[Original equipment manufacturer|OEM]] pickups made by [[Seymour Duncan]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wayneguitars.com/history.html|title=History|publisher=Wayne Guitars|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125065939/http://www.wayneguitars.com/history.html|archivedate=November 25, 2010}}</ref> and were copies of DiMarzio Super Distortion pickups. Seymour Duncan apparently rewound a Gibson PAF for Van Halen around early 1978.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vhlinks.com/pages/interviews/evh/gp122979.php|title=Interviews - Eddie Van Halen|date=December 29, 1979|publisher=vhlinks.com}}</ref>
His later guitars include various [[Kramer Guitars|Kramer]] models from his period of endorsement for that company (most notably the Kramer 5150, from which Kramer in its Gibson-owned days based their Kramer 1984 design, an unofficial artist signature model) and three signature models: the Ernie Ball/[[Music Man (company)|Music Man]] Edward van Halen Model (which continues as the [[Ernie Ball]] Axis), the [[Peavey Electronics|Peavey]] EVH Wolfgang (which has been succeeded by a similar guitar called the HP Special), and the Charvel EVH Art Series, on which Van Halen does the striping before they are painted by Charvel. His current deal is with Fender, making the EVH series of striped guitars, Wolfgang guitars, and EVH amps.
In an interview in ''[[Guitar World]]'' magazine in July 1985, Van Halen states that his "brown sound" is "...basically a tone, a feeling that I'm always working at ... It comes from the person. If the person doesn't even know what that type of tone I'm talking about is, they can't really work towards it, can they?" In an interview with ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine in June 2015, he states that with the expression "brown sound" he actually tried to describe the sound of his brother Alex Van Halen's [[snare drum]], which he thought "...sounds like he’s beating on a log. It’s very organic. So it wasn’t my brown sound. It was Alex's." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/6605131/eddie-van-halen-synesthesia-rumors-brown-sound|title=Does Eddie Van Halen See Colors When He Hears Music? The Guitarist Addresses the Rumors|publisher=Billboard}}</ref> <!--This section is full of [[WP:OR]], and has no references to EVH actually detuning his B string. If I've missed something, please reference and readd.-->
===Patents=== Van Halen is the inventor on {{patent|US|4656917}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/patents?id=-QgyAAAAEBAJ|title=Musical instrument support|publisher=google.com|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}</ref> The main claim is for a supporting member on the back of a stringed instrument, allowing the musician to play and/or fret the instrument in new ways.
He is the lead inventor of {{patent|US|7183475}},<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/patents/US7183475|title=Stringed instrument with adjustable string tension control|publisher=US Patent|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}</ref> for the [http://www.dtuna.com/index.php D-Tuna] he invented to enable a non-floating Floyd Rose-equipped guitar to quickly change the tuning of the low E string by a whole step.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
Another patent naming Van Halen as inventor is [http://www.google.com/patents/USD388117 D388117]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/patents/USD388117|title=Guitar peghead|publisher=Google.com|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}</ref> for the headstock design for the EVH Wolfgang guitars.
==Personal life== On August 29, 1980, Eddie met actress [[Valerie Bertinelli]] at a Van Halen concert in [[Shreveport, Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite web|title=A Guitar Hero Picks His Bride|url=http://ew.com/article/1997/04/11/guitar-hero-picks-his-bride|website=EW.com|accessdate=March 12, 2017|date=April 11, 1997}}</ref> They married in California on April 11, 1981; and have one child, a son, [[Wolfgang Van Halen|Wolfgang]] (born March 16, 1991).
After his father's death in December 1986 and his brother Alex's eventual sobriety in April 1987, Eddie Van Halen struggled with drug and alcohol abuse on and off for twenty years. In April 1988, he was hospitalized with [[dengue fever]] while on a wedding anniversary vacation in Australia. On September 2, 1994, he made his first attempt at sobriety.
Suffering from lingering injuries from past high-risk acrobatic stage antics and crashes, Van Halen underwent [[hip replacement surgery]] in November 1999, after his chronic [[avascular necrosis]], with which he was diagnosed in 1995, became unbearable.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nndb.com/event/307/000111971|title=Hip Replacement Surgery|publisher=NNDB}}</ref> In April 2001, Van Halen confirmed he had been undergoing treatment for [[tongue cancer]] since May 2000. The subsequent surgery removed roughly a third of his tongue. He was declared cancer-free in May 2002.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
Since the 2004 tour, Van Halen had largely disappeared from the public eye, with the exception of occasional appearances including the 14th annual [[Elton John]] Academy Awards party and a performance at a [[Kenny Chesney]] concert. In December 2004, Van Halen attended [[Dimebag Darrell|"Dimebag" Darrell Abbott]]'s funeral, and donated the black and yellow guitar featured on the ''Van Halen II'' album inlay, stating that it was always a favorite of Dimebag's. The guitar was put in Darrell's [[Kiss Kasket]] and he was buried with it.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Pantera|series=VH1: Behind the Music|serieslink=Behind the Music|network=[[VH1]]|minutes=38}}</ref>
On December 5, 2005, Van Halen's wife, [[Valerie Bertinelli]], filed for divorce in Los Angeles Superior Court, after four years of separation, which was finalized on December 20, 2007. On March 8, 2007, Van Halen announced on the official band website that Van Halen was entering rehabilitation for unspecified reasons. However, both Sammy Hagar and Michael Anthony have made statements indicating that Van Halen's personality had changed due to alcohol abuse.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
Van Halen emerged from rehabilitation and appeared publicly as an honorary official during a [[NASCAR]] race at [[Phoenix International Raceway]] on April 21, 2007. He unveiled a new [[Fender Stratocaster]] with a paint job made for the NASCAR races before the ceremony. In 2007, Van Halen was honored in the [[Xbox 360]] version of ''[[Guitar Hero II]]''.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
On October 6, 2008, Van Halen proposed to his girlfriend, Janie Liszewski, an actress and stunt-woman who became Van Halen's publicist in 2007. The two married on June 27, 2009, at his [[Studio City, Los Angeles|Studio City]] estate, with his son Wolfgang and Bertinelli in attendance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20288147,00.html|title=Eddie Van Halen – in Flip-Flops – Weds Girlfriend|date=June 27, 2009|publisher=People}}</ref> Eddie's brother Alex officiated the ceremony, while his son served as best man.<ref>{{cite news|author=Kate Ward|title=Eddie Van Halen marries|url=http://news-briefs.ew.com/2009/06/eddie-van-halen-marries.html|work=EW.com|date=June 30, 2009|accessdate=July 1, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090629225141/http://news-briefs.ew.com/2009/06/eddie-van-halen-marries.html|archivedate=June 29, 2009}}</ref> On January 1, 2011, Eddie and Wolfgang Van Halen attended Bertinelli's remarriage.
In mid-January 2011, he attended the winter [[NAMM Show]] to present his new Wolfgang guitars, sharing the Fender booth with fellow guitar player [[Yngwie Malmsteen]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
In August 2012, Van Halen underwent an emergency surgery for a severe bout of [[diverticulitis]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Chad Childers|title=Eddie Van Halen Undergoes Emergency Surgery|url=http://ultimateclassicrock.com/eddie-van-halen-undergoes-emergency-surgery|work=Ultimate Classic Rock|date=August 29, 2012|accessdate=August 29, 2012}}</ref> His recovery time was four to six months, causing Van Halen to postpone their Japanese tour, which was originally scheduled to begin in November 2012.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
Eddie has donated 75 of his personal guitars to [[The Mr. Holland's Opus Foundation]] stating: "I wanted to give back to the community, and especially kids in need who want an instrument but didn’t have the opportunity I had. I wanted to donate instruments because I have so many guitars and nobody would take them... until we found Mr. Holland’s Opus."<ref>{{cite web|title=Eddie Van Halen Interview Oct. 2016 - Mr. Holland's Opus Foundation|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YgG1hePhWoU|website=Youtube|accessdate=December 5, 2016|date=October 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=EDDIE VAN HALEN Talks About Working With MR. HOLLAND'S OPUS FOUNDATION (Video)|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/eddie-van-halen-talks-about-working-with-mr-hollands-opus-foundation-video|website=blabbermouth.net|accessdate=December 5, 2016|date=October 20, 2016}}</ref>
==Discography== {{Main article|Van Halen discography}} * ''[[Van Halen (album)|Van Halen]]'' (1978) * ''[[Van Halen II]]'' (1979) * ''[[Women and Children First]]'' (1980) * ''[[Fair Warning (Van Halen album)|Fair Warning]]'' (1981) * ''[[Diver Down]]'' (1982) * ''[[1984 (Van Halen album)|1984]]'' (1984) * ''[[5150 (album)|5150]]'' (1986) * ''[[OU812]]'' (1988) * ''[[For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge]]'' (1991) * ''[[Balance (Van Halen album)|Balance]]'' (1995) * ''[[Van Halen III]]'' (1998) * ''[[A Different Kind of Truth]]'' (2012)
==Other work== Eddie Van Halen has appeared on several projects outside of his eponymous band. * 1978: **Van Halen appeared on a [[Ted Templeman]]-[[Donn Landee]] collaboration. **Featured on [[Nicolette Larson]]'s [[Nicolette (album)|debut album]]; track: "Can't Get Away From You". * 1982: Invited by [[Quincy Jones]] to play guitar on [[Michael Jackson]]'s "[[Beat It]]" on the album ''[[Thriller (Michael Jackson album)|Thriller]]''; [[Steve Lukather]] of [[Toto (band)|Toto]] played the main [[Riff|guitar riff]] and rhythm, while Van Halen played the guitar solo. * 1983: Collaborated with [[Queen (band)|Queen]] lead guitarist [[Brian May]] on the ''[[Star Fleet Project]]'', a three-track [[Extended play|EP]] consisting of a rock-styled rendition of the theme to the popular [[anime]] children's show, a May-penned track (''Let Me Out''), and an improvised blues track (''Blues Breaker''). * 1984: **Recorded several instrumentals for the movie ''[[The Wild Life (film)|The Wild Life]]''; however, only ''Donut City'' was included on the soundtrack album **Van Halen provided the score for the 1984 television film, ''The Seduction of Gina''. * 1987: **Van Halen played bass on Sammy Hagar's 1987 [[solo album]] ''[[I Never Said Goodbye]]''. **On February 28, he appeared on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' as a guest musician with [[G. E. Smith]] and the [[Saturday Night Live Band]] when Valerie Bertinelli hosted the show; also appeared in one sketch with Bertinelli. * 1989: Played bass on the opening track ''Twist the Knife'' from [[Steve Lukather]]'s [[Lukather|debut album]], as well as providing the guitar part, which was taken from an outtake from the ''5150'' album titled ''I Want Some Action''. * 1992: After asking [[Thomas Dolby]] for his help with his studio equipment, Eddie agreed to play on two of his songs, "Eastern Bloc" and "Close but no Cigar" on Dolby's album ''[[Astronauts & Heretics]]''. * 1994: Co-wrote the riff of a song with [[Black Sabbath]] members, [[Tony Martin (British singer)|Tony Martin]], [[Tony Iommi]] and [[Geezer Butler]], called "Evil Eye" on the ''[[Cross Purposes]]'' album, but he was not credited due to record company restrictions.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sharpe-Young|first1=Garry|title=Metal: The Definitive Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KNrV3iQ_qrIC&lpg=PA27&ots=dU3F5ndvJf&dq=evil%20eye%20black%20sabbath%20van%20halen&pg=PA27#v=snippet&q=evil%20eye%20eddie&f=false|publisher=Jawbone Press|accessdate=December 5, 2016|date=January 1, 2007}}</ref> * 1996: **Played guitar and bass on Rich Wyman's album ''Fatherless Child''; the songs were recorded between February 1993 and early 1994; he also was co-producer along with Rich Wyman and [[Andy Johns]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.richwyman.com/music|title=RICH WYMAN - Music|publisher=Rich Wyman|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}</ref> **Has done soundtrack work for movies such as ''[[Over the Top (film)|Over The Top]]'' ("Winner Takes It All", a collaboration with Sammy Hagar), ''[[Twister (1996 film)|Twister]]'' (the instrumental "[[Respect the Wind]]"), and ''[[Lethal Weapon 4]]'' (the track "Fire in the Hole" from Van Halen III). * 1998: Performed guitar solos for the [[Roger Waters]] song "Lost Boys Calling" from the film [[The Legend of 1900]]. * 2006: Recorded two new instrumental tracks ("Rise" and "Catherine"), which debuted in an unusual format: in a pornographic feature entitled ''Sacred Sin'' directed by a friend of the guitarist, well known adult director [[Michael Ninn]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spin.com/features/news/2006/07/060727_eddievanhalen|title=Eddie Van Halen Scores Porn|website=spin.com|accessdate=June 1, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060823155657/http://www.spin.com/features/news/2006/07/060727_eddievanhalen|archivedate=August 23, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avn.com/index.php?Primary_Navigation=Articles&Action=View_Article&Content_ID=272492|title=AVN|publisher=Spin|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}</ref> * 2009: Played a cameo role in the season seven premiere of the sitcom ''[[Two and a Half Men]]'', where he plays the main riff from "As Is" from ''A Different Kind of Truth''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eddie Van Halen on Two and a Half Men|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e1fYpkbq8jM|accessdate=December 1, 2017}}</ref> * 2013: Appeared on two tracks of [[LL Cool J]]'s album ''[[Authentic (LL Cool J album)|Authentic]]'': "Not Leaving You Tonight" and "We're The Greatest".{{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
==Hollywood Rock Walk== Van Halen is on the Hollywood Rock Walk located in front of [[Guitar Center|Guitar Center's]] [[Hollywood]] store on [[Sunset Boulevard]].

{{short description|Member of the group of Tungusic languages}} {{Infobox language |name=Evenki |nativename=Эвэды̄ турэ̄н{{harvnb|Boldyrev|1994|p=494}}
{{MongolUnicode|{{Mousetext|ᠧᠠᠩᠬᠢ|evenki}} |v}} |states=[[China]], [[Russia]] |region=[[Inner Mongolia]] and [[Heilongjiang]] in China; [[Krasnoyarsk Krai]] in Russia |ethnicity=[[Evenks]] |speakers=15,800 |date=2007–2010 |ref={{Cite news|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/evn|title=Evenki|work=Ethnologue|access-date=2018-05-07|language=en}} |script=[[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]], [[Latin script|Latin]], [[Mongolian script|Mongolian]] (experimentally) |familycolor=Altaic |fam1=[[Tungusic languages|Tungusic]] |fam2=Northern |fam3=Evenki group |iso3=evn |glotto=even1259 |glottorefname=Evenki |notice=IPA }} '''Evenki''' {{IPAc-en|eɪ|ˈ|v|ɛ|n|k|i}},Also spelled Ewenki, Ewenke, or Owenke and previously conflated with Solon or Suolun formerly known as '''Tungus'''The people speaking Evenki were also called "Tungusy". According to {{harvnb|Nedjalkov|1997|p=xix}}, "Tungus" could be a Chinese exonym. or '''[[Solon people|Solon]]''', is the largest member of the northern group of [[Tungusic languages]], a group which also includes [[Even language|Even]], [[Negidal language|Negidal]], and (the more closely related) [[Oroqen language]]. The name is sometimes wrongly given as "Evenks". It is spoken by [[Evenks]] in [[Russia]] and [[China]]. In certain areas the influences of the [[Yakut language|Yakut]] and the [[Buryat language|Buryat]] languages are particularly strong. The influence of Russian in general is overwhelming (in 1979, 75.2% of the Evenkis spoke Russian, rising to 92.7% in 2002). Evenki children were forced to learn Russian at Soviet residential schools, and returned with a “poor ability to speak their mother tongue...".{{Cite journal|url=https://munin.uit.no/handle/10037/7776|title=The role of the new Evenkiness in the Evenki language revitalization: the case of the Sakha Republic (Yakutia)|last=Sivtseva|first=Mira|date=20 May 2015|website=Muin Open Research Archive|access-date=}} The Evenki language varies considerably among its dialects which are divided into three large groups: the northern, the southern and the eastern dialects. These are further divided into minor dialects. A [[written language]] was created for Evenkis in the [[Soviet Union]] in 1931, first using a [[Latin script|Latin alphabet]], and from 1937 a Cyrillic one.{{harvnb|Atknine|1997|p=117}} In China, Evenki is written experimentally in the [[Mongolian script]].{{harvnb|Kara|2006|p=146}} The language is generally considered [[endangered language|endangered]].Grenoble; Janhunen ==Genetic affiliation== Evenki is a member of the [[Tungusic languages|Tungusic family]]. Its similarity to [[Manchu language|Manchu]], the best-documented member of the family, was noted hundreds of years ago, first by botanist [[Peter Simon Pallas|P. S. Pallas]] in the late 18th century, and then in a more formal linguistic study by [[Matthias Alexander Castrén|M. A. Castren]] in the mid-19th century, regarded as a "pioneer treatise" in the field of Tungusology.{{harvnb|Atknine|1997|p=111}} The exact internal structure of the Tungusic family is a matter of some debate. Some scholars propose two sub-families: one for Manchu, and another for all the other Tungusic languages, including Evenki.{{harvnb|Whaley|Grenoble|Li|1999|p=286}} [[SIL International]]'s [[Ethnologue]] divides Tungusic into two sub-families, Northern and Southern, with Evenki alongside [[Even language|Even]] and [[Negidal language|Negidal]] in the Northern sub-family, and the Southern family itself subdivided into Southwestern (among which Manchu) and Southeastern ([[Nanai language|Nanai]] and others).{{harvnb|Lewis|2009|loc=[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_family.asp?subid=7-16]}} Others propose three or more sub-families, or at the extreme a [[dialect continuum|continuum]] with Manchu at one end and Evenki at the other. ==Dialects== Bulatova enumerated 14 dialects and 50 sub-dialects within Russia, spread over a wide geographical area ranging from the [[Yenisei River]] to [[Sakhalin]]. These may be divided into three major groups primarily on the basis of phonology:{{harvnb|Atknine|1997|p=116}} #Northern (spirant) ##Ilimpeya: Ilimpeya, Agata and Bol'shoi, Porog, Tura, Tutonchany, Dudinka/Khantai ##Yerbogachen: Yerbogachen, Nakanno #Southern (sibilant) ##Hushing ###Sym: Tokma or Upper Nepa, Upper Lena or Kachug, Angara ###Northern Baikal: Northern Baikal, Upper Lena ##Hissing ###Stony Tunguska: Vanavara, Kuyumba, Poligus, Surinda, Taimura or Chirinda, Uchami, Chemdal'sk ###Nepa: Nepa, Kirensk ###Vitim-Nercha/Baunt-Talocha: Baunt, Talocha, Tungukochan, Nercha #Eastern (sibilant-spirant) ##Vitim-Olyokma dialect: Barguzin, Vitim/Kalar, Olyokma, Tungir, Tokko ##Upper Aldan: Aldan, Upper Amur, Amga, Dzheltulak, Timpton, Tommot, Khingan, Chul'man, Chul'man-Gilyui ##Uchur-Zeya: Uchur, Zeya ##Selemdzha-Bureya-Urmi: Selemdzha, Bureya, Urmi ##Ayan-Mai: Ayan, Aim, Mai, Nel'kan, Totti ##Tugur-Chumikan: Tugur, Chumikan ##Sakhalin (no subdialects) Evenks in China also speak several dialects. According to [[Ethnologue]], the Hihue or Hoy dialect is considered the standard; Haila’er, Aoluguya (Olguya), Chenba’erhu (Old Bargu), and Morigele (Mergel) dialects also exist. Ethnologue reports these dialects differ significantly from those in Russia. Some works focused on individual Russia dialects include {{harvnb|Gortsevskaya|1936}} (Barguzin), {{harvnb|Andreeva|1988}} (Tommot), and {{harvnb|Bulatova|1999}} (Sakhalin). ==Phonology== The Evenki language typically has CV syllables but other structures are possible.{{harvnb|Nedjalkov|1997|p=314}} Bulatova and Grenoble list Evenki as having 11 possible vowel phonemes; a classical five-vowel system with distinctions between long and short vowels (except in {{IPA|/e/}}) and the addition of a long and short {{IPA|/ə/}},{{harvnb|Bulatova|Grenoble|1999|p=4}} while Nedjalkov claims that there are 13 vowel phonemes.{{harvnb|Nedjalkov|1997|p=309}} Evenki has a moderately small consonant inventory; there are 18 consonants (21 according to Nedjalkov 1997) in the Evenki language and it lacks glides or semivowels. ===Consonants=== Below are tables of Evenki consonant phonemes, including those identified by Nedjalkov (1997) in italics.{{harvnb|Nedjalkov|1997|pp=310–311}}{{harvnb|Campbell|2000|p=548}} {| class="wikitable" |+Evenki consonants !colspan=2| ! [[Labial consonant|Labial]] ! [[Dental consonant|Dental]] ! [[alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! [[Velar consonant|Velar]] |- align=center !colspan=2|[[Nasal stop|Nasal]] |{{IPA|m}} ||{{IPA|n}} || ||{{IPA|ɲ}} ||{{IPA|ŋ}} |- align=center !rowspan=2|[[Plosive consonant|Plosive]] ![[voiceless consonant|voiceless]] |{{IPA|p}} ||{{IPA|t}} || ||{{IPA|tʃ}} ||{{IPA|k}} |- align=center ![[voiced consonant|voiced]] |{{IPA|b}} ||{{IPA|d}} || ||{{IPA|dʒ}}, ''{{IPA|dʲ}}'' ||{{IPA|ɡ}} |- align=center !rowspan=2|[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] ![[voiceless consonant|voiceless]] |{{IPA|f}} || ||{{IPA|s}} || || {{IPA|x}} |- align=center ![[voiced consonant|voiced]] |{{IPA|β}}, ''{{IPA|v}}'' || || || || {{IPA|ɣ}} |- align=center !colspan=2|[[Approximant]] | ''{{IPA|w}}'' ||{{IPA|l}} || ||{{IPA|j}} || |- align=center !colspan=2|[[Trill consonant|Trill]] | || ||{{IPA|r}} || || |} The phoneme ({{IPA|/β/}}) has a word-final [[allophone]], {{IPA|[f]}}, as well as an intervocalic variant, {{IPA|[w]}}. Likewise, some speakers pronounce intervocalic {{IPA|/s/}} as {{IPA|[h]}}. Speakers of some dialects also alternate {{IPA|/b/}} and {{IPA|/β/}}. Consonant inventories given by researchers working on dialects in China are largely similar. The differences noted: Chaoke and Kesingge ''et al.'' give {{IPA|/h/}} instead of {{IPA|/x/}} and lack {{IPA|/β/}}, {{IPA|/ɣ/}}, or {{IPA|/ɲ/}}; furthermore, Kesingge ''et al.'' give {{IPA|/dʐ/}} instead of {{IPA|/dʒ/}}.{{harvnb|Dular|2009|p=339}}{{harvnb|Kesingge|Cidaltu|Alta|Norbu|1983|p=6}} === Vowels === Below is a chart of Evenki vowels found among Russian dialects, including those identified by Nedjalkov (1997) in italics. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Evenki vowels (Russian dialects) ! !![[Front vowel|Front]] !! colspan="2" | [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! !!unrounded !!unrounded !!rounded |- ! [[Close vowel|Close]] | {{IPA|i}}, {{IPA|iː}}
''{{IPA|ɪ}}, {{IPA|ɪː}}'' ||
''{{IPA|ɯ}}'' || {{IPA|u}}, {{IPA|uː}}
''{{IPA|ʊ}}, {{IPA|ʊː}}'' |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | {{IPA|eː}}

[[Open vowel|Open]] | {{IPA|a}}, {{IPA|aː}} || || |} The vowel inventory of the Chinese dialects of Evenki, however, is markedly different (Chaoke, 1995, 2009):{{harvnb|Dular|2009|pp=330–332}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Evenki vowels (Chinese dialects) ! !![[Front vowel|Front]] !![[Central vowel|Central]] !! colspan="2" | [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! !!unrounded !!rounded !!unrounded !!rounded |- ! [[Close vowel|Close]] | {{IPA|i}}, {{IPA|iː}} || {{IPA|ʉ}}, {{IPA|ʉː}} || || {{IPA|u}}, {{IPA|uː}} |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | {{IPA|e}}, {{IPA|eː}} || {{IPA|ɵ}}, {{IPA|ɵː}} || {{IPA|ə}}, {{IPA|əː}} || {{IPA|o}}, {{IPA|oː}} |- ! [[Open vowel|Open]] | {{IPA|a}}, {{IPA|aː}} || || || |} Like most [[Tungusic languages]], Evenki employs vowel harmony—suffix vowels are matched to the vowel in the root. However, some vowels – {{IPA|/i, iː, u, uː/}} – and certain suffixes do not adhere to the rules of vowel harmony. Knowledge of the rules of vowel harmony is fading, as vowel harmony is a complex topic for elementary speakers to grasp, the language is severely endangered (Janhunen), and many speakers are multilingual. ===Syllable structure=== Possible syllable structures include V, VC, VCC, CV, CVC, and CVCC.{{harvnb|Dular|2009|p=348}} In contrast to dialects in Russia,{{citation needed|date=April 2011}} dialects in China do not have /k/, /ŋ/, nor /r/ in word-initial position. ==Alphabets== ===Russia=== The creation of the Evenki alphabet began in the 1920s. In May 1928, researcher [[Vasilevich, Glafira Makarievna|G. M. Vasilevich]] ([[:ru:Василевич, Глафира Макарьевна|ru]]) prepared for the Evenk students who studied in Leningrad the “Memo to Tungus-vacationers”. It was a small textbook duplicated on the glass{{cite book| author = Г. М. Василевич | chapter = | url = | title = Памятка тунгусам-отпукникам | orig-year = | agency = | edition = |location= Л. |year= 1928 |publisher= |at= |volume= |issue = | pages = | page = | series = | isbn = | ref = }}. It used the Vasilyevich Evenki alphabet on a Latin graphic basis. A year later, she compiled the “First Book for Reading in the Tungus Language” (''Әwәnkil dukuwuntin''){{cite book| author = | chapter = | url = | title = Эвенкийская литература | orig-year = | agency = В. Огрызко | edition = {{nowrap|1000 экз}} |location= М. |year= 2006 |publisher= Литературная Россия |volume= |issue = | pages = 10–12| series = | isbn = 978-5-7809-0094-8| ref = }}. This alphabet had the following composition: ''Aa Bb HH Dd Ӡӡ Ee Әә Gg Hh Ii Kk Ll Mm Nn ​​Ŋŋ Oo Pp Rr Ss Tt Uu Ww Yy''; it also included the diacritical marks: a macron, to indicate the longitude of the sound, and a sub-letter comma, to indicate palatalization{{cite journal |author = Я. П. Алькор (Кошкин) |editor= |format= |url= http://dlib.rsl.ru/viewer/01005509754#?page=20 |title= Письменность народов Севера |type= |origyear= | agency = |edition= Культура и письменность востока |location= М. |date= 1931 |year= 1931 |publisher= ВЦК НА |volume= |issue= X |pages = 12–31 |series= |isbn = |issn = |doi = |bibcode = |pmid = |ref= |archiveurl = |archivedate = |language= |quote= }}. In 1930, it was decided to create a written language for the majority of the peoples of the North of the USSR. The Latin alphabet was chosen as its graphic basis. In the same year, the project of the Evenki alphabet was proposed by Ya. P. Alcor. This project differed from Vasilevich’s alphabet only by the presence of letters for displaying Russian borrowings (''C c, F f, J j, W w, Z z''), as well as using ''V v'' instead of ''W w''. After some refinement, the letter ''Ч'' was replaced by ''Ç ç'', ''V v'' by ''W w'', and the letter ''Y y'' was excluded. In May 1931, the Evenki romanized alphabet was officially approved, and in 1932 regular publishing began on it. The basis of the literary language was laid the most studied nepsky dialect (north of the Irkutsk region){{cite book| author = | chapter = | url = | title = Письменные языки мира: Языки Российской Федерации | orig-year = | agency = | edition = {{nowrap|1000 экз}} |location= М. |year= 2003 |publisher= Academia |volume= 2 |issue = | pages = 648–649| series = | isbn = 978-5-87444-191-3| ref = }}. The official [[Latinisation in the Soviet Union|Latinized]] Evenk alphabet, in which book publishing and schooling were conducted, looked like this{{cite book| author = Г. М. Василевич | chapter = | chapter-url = | format = | url = https://vivaldi.nlr.ru/bx000023311/view#page=14 | title = Учебник эвенкийского (тунгусского) языка | orig-year = | agency = | edition = {{nowrap|5200 экз}} |location= М.-Л. |year= 1934 |publisher= Гос. уч.-пед. изд-во |volume= |issue = | pages = 14| series = | isbn = | ref = }}: {| style="font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:1.4em; border-color:black; border-width:1px; border-style:solid; border-collapse:collapse; background-color:#F8F8EF" | style="width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;" |A a | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |G g | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |H h | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |I i | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |J j | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |K k | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |L l | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |M m | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |N n | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |Ņ ņ |- | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |Ŋ ŋ | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |O o | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |P p | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |R r | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |S s | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |T t | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |U u | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |W w | style=«width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;» |Z z |} Today, the official written language in [[Russia]] for the evenki language is [[Cyrillic script]]. The script has one additional letter, ӈ, to indicate /ŋ/; it is used only inconsistently in printed works, due to typographical limitations.{{harvnb|Grenoble|Whaley|2003|p=116}} Boldyrev's dictionary uses ң instead.E.g. the entry for кто; {{harvnb|Boldyrev|1994|p=173}} Other sounds found in Evenki but not Russian, such as /dʒ/, lack devoted letters. Instead "д" stands in for both /d/ and /dʒ/; when the latter pronunciation is intended, it is followed by one of Cyrillic's [[iotation|iotified]] letters, similar to the way those letters cause [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalization]] of the preceding consonant in Russian. However orthographic decisions like these have resulted in some confusion and transfer of Russian phonetics to Evenki among younger speakers. For example, the spellings "ди" and "ды" were intended to record [dʒi] and [di] (i.e. the same vowel sound). However, in Russian "и" and "ы" are respectively two different vowels /i/ and /ɨ/.{{harvnb|Grenoble|Whaley|2003|p=117}} Long vowels are indicated with macrons. {| style="font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:1.4em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;" | Ю ю | style="width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;" | Я я | | | | | | |} ===China{{anchor|Evenki alphabet}}=== In the "Imperial History of the National Languages of Liao, Jin, and Yuan" ({{zh|t=欽定遼金元三史國語解|p=Qīndìng liáo jīn yuán sān shǐ guóyǔ jiě}}) commissioned by the [[Qianlong Emperor]], the [[Manchu alphabet]] is used to write Evenki words. Evenki in [[China]] is now written in the [[Latin script]] and experimentally in the [[Mongolian script]]. Evenki scholars made an attempt in the 1980s to create standard written forms for their language, using both Mongolian script and a [[pinyin]]-like Latin spelling. They published an Evenki–Mongolian–Chinese dictionary ({{harvnb|Kesingge|Cidaltu|Alta|Norbu|1983}}) with Evenki words spelled in IPA, a pinyin-like orthography, and Mongolian script, as well as a collection of folk songs in IPA and Mongolian script (and Chinese-style [[numbered musical notation]]).{{harvnb|Kara|2006|p=133}} The orthographic system developed by Chinese Evenki scholars reflects differences between Evenki and Mongol [[phonology]]. It uses both {{MongolUnicode|ᠬ|evn|valign=middle}} and {{MongolUnicode|ᠭ|evn|valign=middle}} (usually romanised from Mongolian as ''q'' and ''ɣ'') for /g/.{{harvnb|Kara|2006|p=142}} The system uses double letters in both Mongolian and Latin to represent most long vowels; however for /ɔː/ ''ao'' is written instead of ''oo''. The same scholars' collection of songs has some orthographic differences from the table below; namely, long vowels are occasionally written not just doubled but also with an intervening [[silent letter|silent]] {{MongolUnicode|ᠭ|evn|valign=middle}} (''ɣ''), showing clear orthographic influence from the [[Mongolian language]]. In medial and final positions, ''t'' is written in the [[Manchu script]] form {{MongolUnicode|ᡨ|evn|valign=middle}}.{{harvnb|Kara|2006|pp=139–142}} "Evenki" itself is spelled ''eweŋki'', despite Mongolian orthography usually prohibiting the letter combination ''ŋk''. The vowel inventory of this system is also rather different from that of Chaoke (1995, 2009). {| style="font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:1.4em; border-color:black; border-width:1px; border-style:solid; border-collapse:collapse; background-color:#F8F8EF" | style="width:3em; text-align:center; padding: 3px;" | {{MongolUnicode|ᠠ|evn}}

{{IPA|/dz/}} | | | |} == Morphology == Evenki is highly agglutinating, suffixing, and not flexive: Each [[morpheme]] is easily recognizable and carries only one piece of meaning. Evenki pronouns distinguish between singular and plural as well as inclusive and exclusive in the first person.{{harvnb|Bulatova|Grenoble|1999|pp=6, 21}} The Evenki language has a rich case system—13 cases, though there is some variation among dialects—and it is a nominative–accusative language.{{harvnb|Bulatova|Grenoble|1999|pp=7–8}} Evenki differentiates between alienable and inalienable possession:{{harvnb|Bulatova|Grenoble|1999|p=13}} alienable possession marks the possessor in the [[nominative case]] and the possessum in the [[possessed case]], while inalienable possession is marked by personal indices.{{harvnb|Nedjalkov|1997|pp=82, 158}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Evenki personal indices ! !! Singular !! Plural |- ! First person | -v || -vun (exclusive)
-t (inclusive) |- ! Second person | -s, -si, -ni || -sun |- ! Third person | -n, -in || -tyn |} Below is a table of cases and suffixes in Evenki, following Nedjalkov (1997): {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Evenki cases and suffixes ! colspan="2" | Case !! Suffix !! Example !! Meaning |- | colspan="2" | [[Nominative case|Nominative]] || - || asatkan || the girl |- | rowspan="3" | [[Accusative case|Accusative]] || indefinite || -ja || e-ja || what? |- | definite || -va, -ma || bi kete-ve himmikte-ve tevle-che-v
I much-ACD [[cowberry]]-ACD gather-PST-1SG || I gathered much [[cowberry]] |- | reflexive-genitive definite || -vi (sg.), -ver (pl.) || hute-kle-vi
child-LOCDIR-REF || to/for [her] own child |- | colspan="2" | [[Genitive case|"Old genitive"]] ''unproductive'' || -ngi || e:kun-ngi
who-GEN || whose? |- | colspan="2" | [[Ablative case|Ablative]] || -duk || e:kun-duk
who-ABL || from whom/where? |- | rowspan="5" | [[Locative case|Locative]] || Locative-Directive || -kle, ikle || hute-kle
child-LOCDIR || for the child |- | [[Dative case|Dative-Locative]] || -du, -tu || tatkit-tu
school-DAT || at/in school |- | [[Allative case|Allative-Locative]] || -tki, -tyki || agi-tki
forest-ALLLOC || (in)to the forest |- | [[Allative case|Allative]] || -la || d'u-la
house-ALL || [enter] into the house |- | [[Elative case|Elative]] || -ditk || oron-ditk
reindeer-ELA || from the reindeer |- | colspan="2" | [[Prolative case|Prolative]] || -li, -duli || nadalla-li
week-PRO
singilgen-duli
snow-PRO || in a week's time

in the snow |- | colspan="2" | [[Instrumental case|Instrumental]] || -t, -di || pektyre:vun-di
gun-INS || with the gun |- | colspan="2" | [[Possessed case|Possessed]] || -gali, -chi, -lan, -tai || muri-chi beje
horse-POS man || a man with a horse; a horseman |- | colspan="2" | [[Semblative case]] || -ngachin, -gechin || lang-ngachin
trap-SEM || like a trap |} Plurals are marked with -il-, -l-, or -r- before the case marker, if any: ''tyge-l-ve'' (cup-PL-ACD) "the cups (accusative);" Ivul-ngi oro-r-in (Ivul-GEN reindeer-PL-3SG-POS), "the reindeer (pl.) of Ivul."{{harvnb|Nedjalkov|1997|p=229}} ==Syntax== Evenki is a [[subject–object–verb]] and [[head-final]] language. The subject is marked according to the nominative case, and the object is in the accusative. In Evenki, the [[indirect object]] precedes the [[direct object]]. ==Literary traditions== The [[Manchu script]] was used to write Evenki ([[Solon people|Solon]]) words in the "Imperial History of the National Languages of Liao, Jin, and Yuan". The Evenki did not have their own writing system until the introduction of the [[Latin script]] in 1931 and the subsequent change to Cyrillic in 1936-7.{{harvnb|Bulatova|Grenoble|1999|p=3}} The literary language was first based on the Nepa dialect of the Southern subgroup, but in the 1950s was redesigned with the Stony Tunguska dialect as its basis. Ethnographer [[S. M. Shirokogoroff]] harshly criticised the "child-like" literary language, and in a 1930s monograph predicted it would quickly go extinct.{{harvnb|Inoue|1991|pp=35–37}} Although textbooks through the 8th grade have been published, "Literary Evenki has not yet achieved the status of a norm which cut across dialects and is understood by speakers of some dialects with great difficulty". However, despite its failure to gain widespread acceptance, within its dialectal base of roughly 5,000 people, it survived and continues in use up to the present.{{harvnb|Atknine|1997|p=118}} Since the 1930s, "folklore, novels, poetry, numerous translations from Russian and other languages", textbooks, and dictionaries have all been written in Evenki.{{harvnb|Nedjalkov|1997|p=xxi}} In [[Tura, Krasnoyarsk Krai|Tura]] (former administrative center of the [[Evenk Autonomous Okrug]]), the local newspaper includes a weekly supplement written in Evenki. ==Language shift and multilingualism== There is a large quantity of Russian loan words in Evenki, especially for technologies and concepts that were introduced by the Russian pioneers in Siberia. "Evenki is spoken in regions with heavy multilingualism. In their daily life the people come into contact with Russian, Buriat and Yakut, and each of these languages had affected the Evenki language. Russian is the lingua franca of the region, part of the Evenki population is bilingual, and part trilingual. All Evenki know Russian relatively well." In 1998 there were approximately 30,000 ethnic Evenkis living in Russia and about 1/3 of them spoke the language. Even a decade ago Bulatova was trying to warn speakers and linguists alike: "There is widespread loss of Evenki and the language can be considered seriously endangered". According to the [[Russian Census (2002)|2002 Russian census]], there are 35,527 citizens of the Russian Federation who identify themselves as ethnically Evenki, but only 7,580 speakers of the language.{{harvnb|Lewis|2009|loc=[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=evn]}} In China, there is an ethnic population of 30,500 but only 19,000 are fluent in Evenki and there are only around 3,000 people who are monolingual in Evenki. Juha Janhunen investigated multilingualism in [[Hulunbuir]] (northern [[Inner Mongolia]]) and the adjoining section of [[Heilongjiang]] (e.g. [[Qiqihar]]) in 1996. He found that most [[Solon people|Solons]] still spoke Evenki, and about half knew [[Daur language]] as well.{{harvnb|Janhunen|1996|p=828}} Furthermore, [[Mongolian language|Mongolian]] functioned as a ''[[lingua franca]]'' among members of all [[ethnic minorities in China|minority groups]] there, as they tended to do their education in Mongolian-[[medium of instruction|medium]] schools. The only Evenki-speakers whom Janhunen knew not to speak Mongolian as a second language were the Reindeer Evenki (sometimes called "Yakut") in the northern part of Hulunbuir, who used [[Russian language|Russian]] as their "language of intercultural communication".{{harvnb|Janhunen|1996|p=833}} Janhunen predicted that all of these languages, including Mongolian, were likely to lose ground to Chinese in coming years.{{harvnb|Janhunen|1996|p=834}} However Chaoke noted more than a decade later that the usage rate of Evenki remained quite high, and that it was still common to find Evenki-speakers who were proficient in three, four, or even five languages.{{harvnb|Dular|2009|p=6}} There is a small population of Mongolized [[Hamnigan]] speakers in Mongolia as well, numbering around 1,000. There is little information regarding revival efforts or Evenki's status now. In 1998, the language was taught in preschools and primary schools and offered as an option in 8th grade. The courses were regarded as an 'ethnocultural component' to bring Evenki language and culture into the curriculum.{{Cite journal|last=Mamontova|first=Nadezhda|date=5 December 2014|title=What Language Do Real Evenki Speak?|doi=10.2753/AAE1061-1959520402|journal=Anthropology & Archeology of Eurasia|volume=52|issue=4|pages=37–75|via=}} Instruction as a second language is also available in the [[Institute of the Peoples of the North]] at [[Herzen University]] (the former St. Petersburg State Pedagogical University). In the 1980s, Christian missionaries working in Siberia translated the Bible into Evenki and a Christian group called the Global Recordings Network records Christian teaching materials in Evenki.{{harvnb|Global Recordings Network|2011}} ==Notes== {{reflist|3}} ==References== {{refbegin|2}} *{{citation|chapter=The Evenki Language from the Yenisei to Sakhalin|last=Atknine|first=Victor|title=Northern Minority Languages: Problems of Survival|series=Senri Ethnological Studies|year=1997|pages=109–121|url=http://ir.minpaku.ac.jp/dspace/bitstream/10502/798/1/SES44_007.pdf|editor-first=Hiroshi|editor-last=Shōji|editor2-first=Juha|editor2-last=Janhunen|oclc=37261684|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722073455/http://ir.minpaku.ac.jp/dspace/bitstream/10502/798/1/SES44_007.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-22|doi=10.15021/00002952|df=}} *{{citation|last=Boldyrev|first=B. Moscow. {{ISBN|978-5-458-59022-8}}. ==External links== {{Incubator|code = evn}} *[http://www.omniglot.com/writing/evenki.htm Omniglot] *{{citation|first=György |last=Kara |url=http://www.indiana.edu/~ceus/u520-evenki-grammar-kara.html |title=Course List: Evenki Grammar |publisher=Indiana University at Bloomington |work=Department of Central Asian Studies |year=2007 |accessdate=2011-04-22}} * http://www.evengus.ru/ *{{cite web|url=http://www.evenkiteka.ru |accessdate=2011-09-08 |script-title=ru:Эвенкитека – Эвенкийская библиотека |language=Russian, Evenki |trans-title=Evenkiteka – The Evenki Library}} {{Languages of Russia}} {{Languages of China}} {{Tungusic languages}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Evenki Language}} [[Category:Agglutinative languages]] [[Category:Evenks]] [[Category:Languages of Russia]] [[Category:Languages of China]] [[Category:Tungusic languages]] [[Category:Endangered languages]] [[Category:Subject–object–verb languages]]

{{ref improve|date=February 2013}} '''Gerhart Friedlander''' (born Friedländer: July 28, 1916 – September 6, 2009)<ref name=NYTObit>{{cite news|title=Gerhart Friedlander, Nuclear Chemist, Dies at 93|first=Vicki|last=Glaser|date=September 12, 2009|accessdate=September 12, 2009|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/12/nyregion/12friedlander.html}}</ref> was a nuclear chemist who worked on the [[Manhattan Project]].
Friedlander was born in [[Munich]], and fled [[Nazi Germany]] for the [[United States of America|United States]] in 1936. After emigrating, he studied at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], earning a [[PhD]].
He spent the bulk of his career at [[Brookhaven National Laboratory]], where he served as head of the [[chemistry]] department. He conducted fundamental research into the mechanics of nuclear reactions, developing models that remained in use at the time of his death. He also co-authored a popular textbook on nuclear chemistry.
While at Berkeley, Friedlander worked with Glenn Seaborg on the discovery of [[Seaborgium]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://manhattanprojectvoices.org/oral-histories/gerhart-friedlanders-interview 2002 Video Interview with Gerhart Friedlander by Atomic Heritage Foundation] Voices of the Manhattan Project *[http://findingaids.cjh.org/?pID=1690147 Guide to the Gerhart Friedlander Collection] at the [[Leo Baeck Institute, New York]].
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Friedlander, Gerhart}} [[Category:1916 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:German emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Manhattan Project people]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley alumni]] [[Category:Brookhaven National Laboratory staff]] [[Category:Members of the United States National Academy of Sciences]]
{{US-chemist-stub}}

{{original research|date=February 2016}} '''Hermes of Philippopolis''' was one of the [[Seventy Disciples]] and was [[bishop]] in Philippopolis in [[Thrace]] (today's [[Plovdiv]], [[Bulgaria]]). ''[[The Shepherd of Hermas]]'' is also traditionally ascribed to him. He is referenced in [[Epistle to the Romans|Romans]] 16:14, and his [[feast day]] is celebrated on May 31, on November 5 with Apostles [[Apostle Patrobas|Patrobas]], [[Apostle Linus|Linus]], [[Apostle Gaius|Gaius]], and [[Apostle Philologos|Philologos]], and on January 4 among the Seventy.
==Life== He was wealthy, but fell into poverty because of [[sin]] and the sins of his sons.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} He was thus supposedly visited by an [[angel]] of [[repentance]], who is said to have stayed with him until the end of his life, during which time he wrote ''The Shepherd of Hermas''{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} He ended his life as a [[martyr]].
==Sources== *St. [[Nikolai Velimirovic]], ''The [[Prologue from Ohrid]]''
==External links== '''Biographical links''' *Apostle Hermas of the Seventy, January 4 ([[Orthodox Church in America|OCA]]) *Apostle Hermas of the Seventy, May 31 (OCA) *Apostle Hermes of the Seventy, November 5 (OCA)
'''Writings by Hermas''' *''Early Christian Writings: The Shepherd of Hermas''
==References== *{{Orthodoxwiki source|title=Apostle Hermas|oldid=79012}}
{{authority control}}

{{Other uses|Krestenitis (disambiguation){{!}}Krestenitis}} {{Other uses|Ioannis Krestenitis (disambiguation){{!}}Ioannis Krestenitis}} {{Infobox person | name = Ioannis Krestenitis
''Ιωάννης Κρεστενίτης'' | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Elis]], (now [[Greece]]) [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|15px|Flag of Greece]] | death_date = | death_place = [[Greece]] [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|15px|Flag of Greece]] | nationality = [[Image:Flag of Greece.svg|15px|Flag of Greece]] [[Greece|Greek]] | occupation = [[Greek War of Independence|Greek revolutionary leader]] }} '''Ioannis Krestenitis''' (Greek: Ιωάννης Κρεστενίτης) was a [[Greece|Greek]] revolutionary leader during the [[Greek War of Independence]]. He was responsible for economics during the revolution in the province of [[Pyrgos, Ilia|Pyrgos]]. At the end, he retired from politics since he was old and moved himself in place with his brother [[Lykourgos Krestenitis]]. ==References== *''The first version of the article is translated and is based from the [[:el:Ιωάννης Κρεστενίτης|article]] at the Greek Wikipedia ([[:el:|el:Main Page]]) {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Krestenitis Ioannis}} [[Category:People of the Greek War of Independence]] [[Category:People from Elis]] [[Category:19th-century Greek people]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]]
