revision.text:
{{for|the Canadian football player|Joe Breen}} {{Infobox person | name = Joseph Breen | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Joseph Ignatius Breen | birth_date = {{birth date|1888|10|14|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1965|12|05|1888|10|14|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles, California]], U.S. | resting_place = [[Holy Cross Cemetery, Culver City]] | nationality = American | education = Gesu Parish School
[[Roman Catholic High School]] | alma_mater = [[Saint Joseph's University|Saint Joseph's College]] | occupation = Film censor, journalist | years_active = 1934–1955 | spouse = {{marriage|Mary Dervin|1914|1965}}; his death | children = 6}} '''Joseph Ignatius Breen''' (October 14, 1888 – December 5, 1965) was an [[United States|American]] film [[Censorship|censor]] with the [[Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America]] who applied the [[Hays Code]] to film production.Staff report (December 8, 1965). Joseph I. Breen, Film Code Chief; Watchdog of Movie Morals For Years Is Dead at 75. ''[[New York Times]]'' ==Early life and career== Breen was the youngest of three sons born to Mary and Hugh A. Breen in [[Philadelphia]]. His father had emigrated from [[Ireland]] and met his mother Mary in New Jersey. Breen was raised in a strict [[Roman Catholic]] home and attended Gesu Parish School until the eighth grade.{{cite book|last=Doherty|first=Thomas|title=Hollywood's Censor: Joseph I. Breen and the Production Code Administration|year=2009|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=0-231-14359-1|pages=11–12, 14}} He then attended [[Roman Catholic High School|Boys Catholic High School]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=b-ocAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UmQEAAAAIBAJ&dq=joseph-breen%20censor&pg=4139%2C3063891|title=Film Censor Finds Censorship Begins at Home — Breen Selects the Movies His Children See|publisher=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|date=August 10, 1934|author=Robbin Coons}} He attended [[Saint Joseph's University|Saint Joseph's College]] but dropped out after two years, after which he worked as a newspaper reporter for fourteen years in Philadelphia, [[Washington, D.C.]], and [[Chicago]]. After working as a reporter, Breen worked for the [[United States Foreign Service]] for four years, serving in [[Kingston, Jamaica]], and in [[Toronto, Ontario|Toronto]], Canada. ==As film censor== ===1934—1941=== Breen was a journalist and an "influential layperson" in the Catholic community. Breen worked for [[Will H. Hays]] as a "troubleshooter" as early as 1931.{{cite journal|jstor=462777|title=The Breening of America|last=Leff|first=Leonard J.|journal=PMLA|volume=106|number=3|date=May 1991|pages=432–445|doi=10.2307/462777}}{{paywall}} In 1933, the Roman Catholic [[National Legion of Decency]] was founded, and began to rate films independently, putting pressure on the industry. In 1933 and 1934 the Legion along with a number of Protestant and women's groups launched plans to boycott films that they deemed immoral.{{cite book |author=Matthew Bernstein |title=Controlling Hollywood: Censorship and Regulation in the Studio Era |year=2000 |isbn=0813527074 |publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dEYoT857G8UC |accessdate=15 February 2013}} The [[Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America]] (MPPDA) had, up until then, enforced the motion picture industry's own self-censorship standards, albeit not very seriously.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ILgyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AOsFAAAAIBAJ&dq=joseph-breen%20censor&pg=1675%2C861119|title=Censors Bloomed With the Talkies|publisher=The Miami News|date=August 3, 1965|author=Bob Thomas|page=2}} Hays, who had been in charge of enforcing this voluntary code since 1927, worried that the NLD's efforts could weaken his own power and that of his office, and hurt industry profits. Hays appointed the "tough Irish Catholic" Breen to head the [[Production Code Administration]] (PCA), a newly created department of the MPPDA, created to administer the [[Motion Picture Production Code]].Pryors, Thomas S. (October 15, 1954). "Breen is Retired as Movie Censor; At Own Request, Director of Code Leaves Office -- Chief Aide Successor", ''[[New York Times]]''; accessed May 4, 2017. Unlike previous attempts at self-censorship, PCA decisions became binding — no film could be exhibited in an American theater without a stamp of approval from the PCA.{{cite book |author=Gregory D. Black |title=Hollywood Censored: Morality Codes, Catholics, and the Movies |year=1996 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0521565928 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ybKqnNNR7hwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Hollywood+Censored:+Morality+Codes,+Catholics,+and+the+Movies&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hIweUZuEJsHe0QG6zoHgBg&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA |accessdate=15 February 2013}} Any producer attempting to do so faced a fine of $25,000.{{cite book |title=The Dame in the Kimono: Hollywood, Censorship, and the Production Code |last1=Leff |first1=Leonard J. |last2=Simmons |first2=Jerold L. |year=2001 |publisher=University Press of Kentucky |location= |isbn=0813190118 |page= |pages= |url= }} After ten years of unsuccessful voluntary codes and expanding local censorship boards, the studio approved and agreed to enforce the codes, and the nationwide production code was enforced starting on July 1, 1934. ''[[Liberty (1924–1950)|Liberty Magazine]]'' wrote in 1936 that Breen's appointment gave him "more influence in standardizing world thinking than Mussolini, Hitler, or Stalin."{{cite journal|last=Wu|first=Tim|title=The Future of Free Speech|journal=The Chronicle of Higher Education|volume=57|number=13|year=2010|authorlink=Tim Wu}} Breen has been accused of [[anti-Semitism]]{{cite book|author=Jill Watts|title=Hattie McDaniel: Black Ambition, White Hollywood|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BCF1N-4ChUEC&pg=PA146|accessdate=May 26, 2013|date=February 6, 2007|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-06-051491-4|page=146}} because of a few personal letters he wrote in the early 1930s. In these letters, he lamented the immorality of the filmmakers. According to author Thomas Doherty, this outburst was likely a reaction to Breen's sudden immersion in the alien Hollywood culture rather than an expression of deeply held beliefs, stating that "The antisemitic bile erupted during the pre-Code era, when Breen, newly arrived in Hollywood, was shocked by the folkways of the locals and anguished by his inability to purify the screen." After 1934, he was "publicly and forthrightly anti-antisemitic."{{cite news|url=http://forward.com/articles/12234/was-hollywood-s-famed-censor-an-antisemite-|publisher=The Jewish Daily Forward|author=Thomas Doherty|title=Was Hollywood's Famed Censor an Antisemite?|date=December 11, 2007|accessdate=May 26, 2013}} [[William Dudley Pelley]], founder of the anti-Semitic organization the [[Silver Legion of America]], believed that Jews controlled the movie industry, which he thought to be the "most effective propaganda medium in America", during the 1930s. Hence he applauded the fact that Breen had assumed the power to censor Hollywood.{{cite book|author=Michael E. Birdwell|title=Celluloid Soldiers: Warner Bros.'s Campaign Against Nazism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mB47-g4wVvMC&pg=PA42|accessdate=May 26, 2013|date=February 1, 2001|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=978-0-8147-9871-3|page=42}} Breen, who also expressed anti-Semitic views{{Cite news|url=https://forward.com/culture/12234/was-hollywood-s-famed-censor-an-antisemite-00948/|title=Was Hollywood’s Famed Censor an Antisemite?|work=The Forward|access-date=2018-08-16}}, was deeply worried that Jewish filmmakers would try to use Nazi mistreatment of Jews during the 1930s as a vehicle for propaganda. He was concerned that Germans would be offended by harsh depiction of Nazis. He specifically warned Hollywood producers to avoid the topic altogether, saying that "[t]here is a strong pro-German and anti-Semitic feeling in this country ... and while those who are likely to approve of an anti-Hitler picture may think well of such an enterprise, they should keep in mind that millions of Americans might think otherwise."{{cite book|author=Bruce Kirle|title=Unfinished Show Business: Broadway Musicals As Works-in-Process|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8KgEhFzJd9YC&pg=PA132|accessdate=May 27, 2013|year=2005|publisher=SIU Press|isbn=978-0-8093-8857-8|page=132}} Breen claimed that plans to make such pictures were being coordinated through the [[Hollywood Anti-Nazi League]], which he claimed was "conducted and financed almost entirely by Jews". As a result of Breen's anticommunist views, the censorship board pressured [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] to drop plans to film [[Sinclair Lewis]]'s anti-fascist novel, ''[[It Can't Happen Here]]''.{{cite book|author1=Clayton R.. Koppes|author2=Gregory D. Black|title=Hollywood Goes to the War: Patriotism, Movies and the Second World War from Ninotchka to Mrs Miniver|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hS37BjbOMmAC&pg=PA22|accessdate=May 27, 2013|year=2000|publisher=Tauris Parke Paperbacks|isbn=978-1-86064-605-8|page=22}} In 1938, largely in response to [[Nazi]] activities in Germany, [[Pope Pius XI]] denounced anti-Semitism, stating that "it is not possible for Christians to take part in anti-Semitism". In response to this encouragement, American Roman Catholics formed the [[Committee of Catholics to Fight Anti-Semitism]]. The two authors of the [[Will H. Hays|Hays Code]], [[Martin Quigley (publisher)|Martin J. Quigley]] and the [[Daniel A. Lord|Rev. Daniel Lord, SJ]], promoted the cause. Quigley asked Breen to help gather statements of support from Catholics in the Hollywood film industry. Breen did so, and issued a statement himself, which said, in part, "In my judgement there is nothing more important for us Catholics to do at the present moment [July 1939] than to use our energies in stemming the tide of racial bigotry and hostility."Doherty 2009, pp. 211–12 ===1941—1954=== Breen retired from the PCA in April 1941, announcing that his departure was due to overwork and exhaustion.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SRNRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=V8oMAAAAIBAJ&dq=joseph-breen%20censor&pg=5941%2C2938965|title=New Censor Sought by Movie Czar|publisher=The Telegraph-Herald|date=April 25, 1941}} Between 1941 and 1942 Breen was the general manager of [[RKO Pictures]]. He returned to the PCA in 1942. By the mid-1950s, Breen's power over Hollywood was diminishing. For instance, [[Samuel Goldwyn]] publicly insisted that the production code be revised. Around the same time, [[Howard Hughes]], owner of RKO, released ''[[The French Line]]'', featuring revealing images of actress [[Jane Russell]] in a bathing suit, despite the fact that Breen had refused to approve the picture for release.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XQ9MAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ASQNAAAAIBAJ&dq=joseph-breen%20censor&pg=3848%2C4857657|title=Hollywood Report|author=Aline Mosby|publisher=Oxnard Press-Courier|date=March 17, 1954}} In 1951, Breen's office refused to approve [[Otto Preminger]]'s film ''[[The Moon Is Blue]]'' because of objections to the dialogue.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=j_srAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pMYEAAAAIBAJ&dq=joseph-breen%20censor&pg=1025%2C6593513|title=Movie Censorship Faces Strongest Challenge Now|author=Bob Thomas|publisher=Times Daily|date=June 9, 1953}} [[United Artists]] backed Preminger in his decision to release the movie without Breen's approval.Fujiwara, Chris, ''The World and Its Double: The Life and Work of Otto Preminger''. New York: Macmillan Publishers 2009; {{ISBN|0-86547-995-X}}, pp. 140-42 In 1954, the same year he retired, in responding to these events in an interview with Aline Mosby, Breen claimed that "[A]fter the events of the past 10 months — ''The French Line'', ''The Moon is Blue'' and Goldwyn — the code is more entrenched than ever before. Those events brought tremendous support from groups all over the country." Breen retired from the PCA and was replaced by Geoffrey Shurlock.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_vlXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qfYDAAAAIBAJ&dq=joseph-breen%20censor&pg=710%2C95570|title=Censors try tempering growing movie violence|author=Bob Thomas|publisher=Spokane Daily Chronicle|date=June 1, 1955}} On his retirement he was presented with an honorary [[Academy Award]] for "his conscientious, open-minded and dignified management of the Motion Picture Production Code".Doherty 2009 p. 5 == Personal life == Breen married Mary Dervin in February 1914, with whom he had six children, three boys and three girls.Doherty 2009 p. 15 Their son Joseph Breen, Jr. was a writer and director.https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0106713/ One of their other children, Thomas, whose right leg was amputated due to a combat injury on [[Guam]] during World War II, was cast in a feature role in [[Jean Renoir]]'s 1950 film [[The River (1951 film)|''The River'']], playing a wounded war veteran. Renoir was not aware at the time that Thomas was Joseph Breen's son.Doherty 2009 pp. 70, 282 After his retirement, Breen moved to [[Phoenix, Arizona]] with his wife Mary. He suffered from poor health in his later years and eventually lost the use of his legs. He died at the age of 77 on December 5, 1965, at the Brentwood Convalescent Home in Los Angeles and was buried at [[Holy Cross Cemetery, Culver City]].Doherty 2009 pp. 346–48 ==Legacy== After Breen's death, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' magazine wrote that Breen was "one of the most influential figures in American culture" and that "more than any single individual, he shaped the moral stature of the American motion picture."Doherty, Thomas Patrick. ''Pre-Code Hollywood: Sex, Immorality, and Insurrection in American Cinema 1930-1934''. New York: Columbia University Press 1999. {{ISBN|0-231-11094-4}}, pg. 9 The trade magazine went on to say that Breen enforced the PCA code "with a potent mix of missionary zeal and administrative tenacity." In the 2004 film ''[[The Aviator (2004 film)|The Aviator]]'', Breen was portrayed by [[Edward Herrmann]]. {{Portal|Biography}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|1033952}} *{{Find a Grave|6848389}} {{Academy Honorary Award}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Breen, Joseph I.}} [[Category:1888 births]] [[Category:1965 deaths]] [[Category:Academy Honorary Award recipients]] [[Category:American male journalists]] [[Category:American journalists]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Burials at Holy Cross Cemetery, Culver City]] [[Category:Censors]] [[Category:Film censorship in the United States]] [[Category:Writers from Philadelphia]] [[Category:Saint Joseph's University alumni]] [[Category:American anti-communists]]

revision.text:
'''Joseph Antoine Soueif''' (in {{lang-ar|يوسف انطوان سويف}}, born on 14 July 1962 in [[Chekka]], [[Lebanon]]) is the current bishop of the [[Maronite Catholic Archeparchy of Cyprus]].
==Life==
Joseph Soueif<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/cypr0.htm GCatholic]</ref> was born in the Lebanese town of Chekka,<ref>[Annuario Pontificio (en italiano). Libreria Editrice Vaticana. 2009. p. 181. {{ISBN|9788820981914}}.]</ref> a coastal village in northern Lebanon, in [[Batroun District]]. He completed his secondary studies at the patriarchal seminary of St. Maron in Ghasim in 1982, and later studied theology at [[Holy Spirit University of Kaslik]], graduating in 1987. He was ordained to the priesthood at the age of twenty-five on 3 September 1987 by the Maronite Archbishop of Tripoli [[Antoine Joubeir]]. In 1992 Soueif received his doctorate at the [[Pontifical Oriental Institute]] in Rome.
His appointment as Archbishop of Archeparchy of Cyprus was on 29 October 2008. The solemn consecration took place on 6 December 2008 being his principal consecrator His Beatitude [[List of Maronite Patriarchs|Maronite Patriarch of Antioch]], [[Nasrallah Boutros Sfeir]] and the Archbishops [[Boutros Gemayel]] of Cyprus and [[Georges Bou-Jaoudé]] of [[Tripoli, Lebanon|Tripoli]] acted as co-consecrators bishops.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bsoueif.html * http://www.typosmaroniton.com/cgibin/hweb?-A=2881&-V=english * http://akouri.blogspot.com.br/2009/01/akouri-congratulates-lebanese-cleric.html
{{DEFAULTSORT:Soueif, Joseph}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Lebanese people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Maronite Catholic bishops]] [[Category:Pontifical Oriental Institute alumni]]

'''Karl Spindler''' (1887-1951) was a German Naval Officer who was involved in an attempt to bring German arms ashore in [[Ireland]] on behalf of Irish rebels as part of the [[Easter Rising]] of 1916.<ref>[http://www.heimatverein-siebengebirge.de/aktivitaet/artikel/spindlere.html Captain Karl Spindler], Siebengebirge e.V.</ref>
==Early life== Spindler was born in the small town of [[Königswinter]], near [[Cologne]], [[Germany]] on 29 May 1887, the son of a quarry owner, Hubert Spindler and his wife Elise (née Fuchs). At an early age Spindler decided to go to sea rather than join the family business, serving for a period as a watch officer on a Lloyd line steamship. He subsequently enlisted in the marine school in [[Bremen]] and the naval academy in [[Sonderburg]], then part of Germany. He served on several ships of the [[German Imperial Navy]] and at the outbreak of the Great War, he was commanding the Polarstern, a guardship for the port of [[Wilhelmshaven]].
==Naval career== On 20 March 1916 Spindler was given instructions by his senior officer to undertake a highly secret and dangerous mission on board a disguised merchant ship and to pick five officers and a crew of 16 to join him on the journey. He was given command of a vessel named ''[[SS Libau|Libau]]'',<ref>[http://corkshipwrecks.net/1916Aud.htm Shipwrecks of Cork Harbour] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130624220152/http://corkshipwrecks.net/1916Aud.htm |date=2013-06-24 }}</ref> a captured British vessel formerly named "Castro" and informed that it was to be falsely flagged as a Norwegian freighter and carry a cargo of weapons to the West Coast of Ireland along with a passenger, Sir [[Roger Casement]]. It was part of a plan to land German arms in Ireland to assist Irish republicans in staging what would become the 1916 Rising. Spindler travelled to [[Berlin]] for further orders and met Casement there. However Casement preferred to travel on board a submarine which would accompany the ''Libau'' which was to be renamed the ''Aud'', the name of a real Norwegian ship, once it went to sea. Casement was later put ashore at Banna Strand in Co. Kerry from the submarine by means of a small collapsible boat. However Casement was arrested soon afterwards on [[Good Friday]], 21 April 1916, and taken prisoner in the Tower of London on charges of High Treason against the [[United Kingdom]]. He was subsequently executed by hanging at Pentonville Prison on 3 August 1916. The uprising had failed. Meanwhile, Spindler's ship, now renamed the ''Aud'', was intercepted by British naval vessels near the [[Blasket Islands]] and forced to sail for [[Cobh]] (then known as Queenstown) where the British had a major naval base. However Spindler instructed his crew to open the ship's sea-valves and blow an explosive charge in the hold. As they left the sinking ship the crew took down the false Norwegian flag she was flying and hoisted the German Imperial flag in its place. They then left the vessel on board two dinghies and were taken prisoners by the British. After some questioning they were taken as prisoners of war to Donington Hall. From there they later escaped only to be recaptured the following day. Spindler was in a weakened state after several bouts of ill-health, and in a [[prisoner exchange]] shortly before the end of the war he was transferred to the Netherlands. He subsequently travelled to the United States where he went on a lecture tour speaking of his ill-fated trip to Ireland and his connections with the Easter Rising. In 1921 Spindler published a book on the "Aud" episode which was translated into English as "The mystery of the Casement ship" or "The Mystery Ship" <ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0B10F83F5810738DDDAA0894D9405B818EF1D3 German Describes Effort to Arm Irish], New York Times, 3 January 1921</ref> and had significant sales and was translated into several languages. He was feted by Irish-American groups in the US and received numerous awards.
==Later life== Although he made several returns to Germany to see his family, Spindler remained in the United States for the rest of his life. During World War II he was detained in an internment camp as an enemy alien as he failed to get permanent residency or naturalization in the US. He was released in poor health at the end of that war. Karl Spindler died on 29 November 1951 in Bismarck, North Dakota.<ref>[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/59359748 Karl M Spindler], findagrave.com</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Spindler, Karl}} [[Category:1887 births]] [[Category:1951 deaths]] [[Category:People from Königswinter]] [[Category:People from the Rhine Province]] [[Category:German non-fiction writers]] [[Category:German military writers]] [[Category:German male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:People of the Easter Rising]] [[Category:Imperial German Navy personnel]] [[Category:World War I prisoners of war held by the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Prisoners in the Tower of London]] [[Category:German prisoners of war in World War I]]

'''Lance Henson''' (born September 20, 1944) is a [[Cheyenne]] [[poet]]. Henson was born in Washington, D.C. and grew up near [[Calumet, Oklahoma]], where his grandparents raised him in the traditions of the Cheyenne tribe. He has published 28 volumes of poetry, which have been translated into 25 languages. He has been described as the "foremost Cheyenne poet now writing."<ref name="Handbook-NA-Lit">Arnett, Carroll ([[Gogisgi]]). "Lance (David) Henson," ''Handbook of Native American Literature''. Wiget, Andrew, ed. Taylor & Francis, 1996, p.445. {{ISBN|0-8153-1560-0}}</ref>
==Early life== Henson was born in [[Washington, D.C.]] on September 20, 1944.<ref name="Handbook-NA-Lit"/> He is of [[Cheyenne]], [[Oglala Lakota|Oglala]], and [[Cajun]] ancestry.<ref name="OK-Writers">[http://www.okhistory.org/writers/bio.php?lname=Henson&fname=Lance "Lance Henson,"] ''Oklahoma Writers: A Literary Tableau'', Oklahoma Historical Society, Accessed June 29, 2015.</ref><ref name="Gannon-242">Gannon, Thomas C. ''Skylark Meets Meadowlark: Reimagining the Bird in British Romantic and Contemporary Native American Literature'', University of Nebraska Press: Lincoln, Nebraska, 2009, p.242. {{ISBN|978-0803220577}}</ref> He grew up near Calumet, Oklahoma, where he was raised by his grandparents, who taught him the traditions and culture of the Cheyenne tribe.<ref name="World-Lit-Today-Summer-1990">Berner, Robert L. "Lance Henson: Poet of the people," ''World Literature Today'', Vol. 64 No. 3, Summer 1990, p.418-421.</ref> After graduating from high school, he served in the [[U.S. Marine Corps]] in the [[Vietnam War]].<ref name="USAO-2004">[https://usao.edu/alumni/henson-lance-david-2004 "Henson, Lance David 2004,"] ''University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma'', Accessed June 29, 2015.</ref><ref name="Velie-263">Velie, p.263</ref> He later became a member of the Cheyenne Dog Soldier Society, an organization of Cheyenne veterans.<ref name="Velie-263"/> He attended Oklahoma College of Liberal Arts (now the [[University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma]]), where he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in English.<ref name="Handbook-NA-Lit"/> He earned a [[Ford Foundation]] Scholarship, which allowed him to undertake graduate studies at the [[University of Tulsa]], where he earned a Master of Arts degree in Creative Writing.<ref name="Handbook-NA-Lit"/><ref name="USAO-2004"/>
==Career== Henson published his first book of poetry, ''Keeper of Arrows'', in 1971, when he was still a student at Oklahoma College of Liberal Arts.<ref name="Indian-News-3-11-2009">Staff Reports. [http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2009/03/11/internationally-known-poet-lance-henson-returns-usao-83032 "Internationally Known Poet Lance Henson Returns to USAO,"] ''Indian Country Today Media Network'', March 11, 2009. Accessed June 29, 2015.</ref> He was part of the State Arts Council of Oklahoma's Artist in Residence Program, through which he conducted poetry workshops throughout the state for 10 years.<ref name="Indian-News-3-11-2009"/> Since then, he has traveled around the world lecturing and doing readings of his poetry.<ref name="USAO-2004"/> In his travels throughout the United States and Europe, he has been a poet in residence at more than 800 schools.<ref>Blaeser, Kimberly M. "Canons and Canonization: American Indian Poetries Through Autonomy, Colonization, Nationalism, and Decolonization," Eric Cheyfitz, ed. ''The Columbia Guide to American Indian Literatures of the United States Since 1945'', Columbia University Press: New York, 2006, p.202. {{ISBN|978-0231511025}}</ref>
At the [[United Nations]] Indigenous Peoples Conference in Geneva in 1988, Henson represented the [[Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes|Southern Cheyenne]].<ref name="World-Lit-Today-Summer-1990"/> In 1993, he was part of a [[United States Information Agency]] tour, in which he lectured in Singapore, Thailand, New Guinea and New Zealand.<ref name="USAO-2004"/> Also in 1993, he was poet-in-residence at the [[University of New Mexico]].<ref name="Cameron-U-3-19-2012">[http://www.cameron.edu/media-releases2012/lance-henson "Cameron University Presents Southern Cheyenne Poet Lance Hanson,"] ''Cameron University'', March 19, 2012. Accessed June 29, 2015.</ref> He was a resident at the [[Millay Colony for the Arts]] in 1995, and he was awarded a Distinguished Native American Scholars residency at the [[Smithsonian Institution]].<ref name="Cameron-U-3-19-2012"/> In 2004, Henson was inducted into the University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma Hall of Fame.<ref name="Indian-News-3-11-2009"/>
He has published 28 volumes of poetry, which have been translated in 25 languages.<ref name="Cameron-U-3-19-2012"/>
Henson lives in Italy, where his works have been popular.<ref name="OK-Writers"/><ref name="Velie-264">Velie, p.264</ref> Many of his books are published in Italian/English editions.<ref name="OK-Writers"/> He returns to Oklahoma every June to take part in the Cheyenne Sun Dance.<ref name="Cameron-U-3-19-2012"/>
In 2013, Henson established an official website where selected recent works are available in advance of publication.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Lance Henson|url = http://www.lancehenson.com|website = Lance Henson|accessdate = 2015-09-18}}</ref>
==Plays== He has written two plays, "Winter Man," which was performed at [[La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club]], and "Coyote Road," which has been performed at Mad River Theater in West Liberty, Ohio, and in [[Versailles, France]].
==Style and influences== Henson's poems draw upon his Cheyenne heritage, incorporating words from the [[Cheyenne language]], Cheyenne philosophy, and Hanson's own social and political commentary.<ref name="Velie-263"/><ref name="Cameron-U-3-19-2012"/><ref name="Velie-211">Velie, p.211</ref> He writes in a minimalist style with no capitalization, punctuation, rhyme, or meter.<ref name="World-Lit-Today-Summer-1990"/> Wilson notes that this style is similar to traditional Cheyenne songs.<ref name="Cambridge-Companion-150">Wilson, Norma C. "America's Indigenous Poetry," ''The Cambridge Companion to Native American Literature'', Joy Porter, Kenneth M. Roemer, eds. Cambridge University Press: Cambridge, 2005. p. 150. {{ISBN|978-0-521-82283-1}}</ref> Imagery of nature and the seasons figures prominently in Henson's works.<ref name="Handbook-NA-Lit"/> He also comments on the status of indigenous peoples, their historic oppression, and modern threats to their cultures.<ref name="Cambridge-Companion-150"/><ref>Pfeiler, Martina. ''Sounds of Poetry: Contemporary American Performance Poets''. Gunter Narr Verlag. 2003, p.31. {{ISSN|0939-8481}} {{ISBN|3-8233-4664-4}}</ref> His work is influenced [[Walt Whitman]], [[N. Scott Momaday]], [[Carl Jung]], [[Herman Melville]], [[Nathaniel Hawthorne]], and [[Mark Twain]].<ref name="OK-Writers"/><ref name="Velie-263"/> Robert Berner also notes references to [[haiku]], [[Li Bai|Li Po]], and [[Du Fu|Tu Fu]] in his works.<ref name="World-Lit-Today-Summer-1990"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== *Velie, Alan R., ed. "Lance Henson," ''American Indian Literature: An Anthology''. Rev. ed. University of Oklahoma Press: Norman, OK, 1991. {{ISBN|0-8061-2331-1}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Henson, Lance}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:20th-century American poets]] [[Category:21st-century American poets]] [[Category:American writers of Native American descent]] [[Category:Cheyenne people]] [[Category:Native American poets]] [[Category:Writers from Oklahoma]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma alumni]] [[Category:University of Tulsa alumni]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox artist | name = Leonard Long | image = Leonard Long.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Long, circa 1984 | birth_name = Leonard Hugh Long | birth_date = {{Birth date|1911|4|25|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Summer Hill, New South Wales]], [[Australia]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2013|11|03|1911|4|25|df=y}} | death_place = [[Melbourne]], Australia | spouse = | field = [[Landscape art|Landscape]] [[painting]] | training = | movement = | works = | patrons = | awards = [[Order of Australia]] <small>(1993)</small> | elected = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | bgcolour = }} '''Leonard Hugh Long''' [[Order of Australia|OAM]] (25 April 1911 – 3 November 2013)<ref name="Obituary">{{cite news|last = Crawford|first = Robert|title = Famous Nowra artist Leonard Long dies at 102|newspaper = South Coast Register|date = 2013-11-04|url = http://www.southcoastregister.com.au/story/1885060/famous-nowra-artist-leonard-long-dies-at-102/?cs=203|accessdate = 2013-11-03}}</ref> was an [[Australia]]n [[Painting|painter]] of the Australian School of landscape painters.
==Early years== Born in Summer Hill, [[New South Wales]], the son of a baker, Long was a landscape artist in oils. He was raised in [[Mittagong]] on the Southern Tablelands of [[New South Wales]] and showed an early aptitude for drawing. He painted his first painting at the age of 16. He started his working life as a [[watch-maker]] in nearby [[Bowral]] later moving to [[Nowra]] for work.<ref name="Long1986"> {{cite book | last = Anon | title = Leonard Long | publisher = Gwynne Publishers | year = 1986 | location = Melbourne | isbn = 1-86252-445-9}} </ref>
==Early career== As a young man Long was a cyclist and rode his push bike long distances including the trip from Nowra back to Mittagong to see his sweetheart Mary whom he later married. In 1934, he and Mary settled in [[Nowra]] where they raised their family. They had twins Ray and Barry in 1936 and a daughter Carmel in 1938. By 1939, Long had become more seriously interested in Landscape Painting and spent more and more of his spare time painting. After returning from his civil service during the Second World War as a precision instrument maker, he sold his watch-making business to his partner and began full-time painting in 1955.<ref name="Long1986"/>
==Exhibitions== During his career, Long held many successful solo exhibitions throughout [[Australia]] and traveled extensively both within Australia and overseas. His first overseas trip was sponsored by the American millionaire John Galvin and the experience made a lasting impression on the artist. He knew and painted with many other Australian artists including [[Albert Namatjira]].<ref name="footsteps">{{cite web | title = In the Artist's Footsteps: Albert Namatjira Biography | publisher = Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs | url = http://www.artistsfootsteps.com/html/namatjira_biography.htm | accessdate = 2010-01-29}}</ref> His works may be found in many private collections and is represented in many public galleries around the world.<ref name="Long1986"/>
==Older years== Long moved to [[Melbourne]] in 1980. On 26 January 1993, Long was awarded a [[Order of Australia|Medal of the Order of Australia]] 'for service to the arts as a painter of Australian landscapes.'<ref>{{cite web|last=Commonwealth of Australia|title=Its an Honour|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=870432&search_type=simple&showInd=true|work=www.itsanhonour.gov.au|publisher=Honours and Awards Branch, Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet|accessdate=2010-06-20|location=Canberra|date=1993-01-26}}</ref> At the age of 100, Long continued to paint every day and staged his centenary exhibition on 14 May 2011 at Kim Nelson Fine Art & Editions in [[Yass, New South Wales|Yass]], New South Wales, not far from the nation's capital, [[Canberra]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.yass.nsw.gov.au/events/pages/14713.html | title = Leonard Long Centenary Exhibition | publisher = Yass Valley Council | accessdate = 28 March 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110327135835/http://www.yass.nsw.gov.au/events/pages/14713.html | archivedate = 27 March 2011 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> He attributed his continued health to an active life and a medicinal scotch in the afternoon.<ref name="Centenary">{{Cite news|last = Prytz|first = Anna|title = Donvale artist long drawn to nature|newspaper = Manningham Leader|publisher = [[News Limited]]|date = 2011-05-07|url = http://manningham-leader.whereilive.com.au/news/story/donvale-artist-long-drawn-to-nature/|accessdate = 2011-05-09|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110728095526/http://manningham-leader.whereilive.com.au/news/story/donvale-artist-long-drawn-to-nature/|archivedate = 28 July 2011|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
==Death== Long died after a short illness on November 3, 2013 at the age of 102.<ref name="Obituary"/>
==Notes== {{reflist|1}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Long, Leonard}} [[Category:1911 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Australian painters]] [[Category:Australian landscape painters]] [[Category:Recipients of the Medal of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Australian centenarians]] [[Category:People from Sydney]] [[Category:Watchmakers (people)]]

{{use American English|date=July 2015}} {{use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} This is a '''list of women''' who have won the '''[[Miss USA]]''' beauty pageant. Eight Miss USA winners have gone on to become [[Miss Universe]] and are indicated in bold face. From 1967 on, a runner-up was selected to replace any Miss USA titleholder who won the Miss Universe pageant. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- !Year !Miss USA !Hometown !State !Age{{efn|Ages at the time of Miss USA}} !Height !Placement at Miss Universe !Image !Notes |- style="background:#FFFACD;" | [[Miss USA 1952|1952]] | [[Jackie Loughery]] | [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]] | [[Miss New York USA|New York]] | 22 | {{convert|5|ft|4|in|cm|abbr=on}} | Top 10 | | |- style="background:#FFFF66;" | [[Miss USA 1953|1953]] | [[Myrna Hansen]]{{cite news|title=Chicagoan Named Miss US|publisher=Spokane Daily Chronicle|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aXYzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hPYDAAAAIBAJ&dq=myrna-hansen&pg=6857%2C3673014|date=1953-07-16|page=6}} | [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] | [[Miss Illinois USA|Illinois]] | 18 | {{convert|5|ft|7|in|cm|abbr=on}} | 1st Runner-Up | | |- |-style="background-color:gold; font-weight: bold" | [[Miss USA 1954|1954]] | [[Miriam Stevenson]]{{cite news|title=Dixie Beauty Picked as "Miss Universe"|date=1954-07-24|publisher=The Miami News|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NywyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fOgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5577,1390737&dq=miriam-stevenson&hl=en|last=Associated Press|page=1}} | [[Winnsboro, South Carolina|Winnsboro]] | [[Miss South Carolina USA|South Carolina]] | 21 | {{convert|5|ft|6|in|cm|abbr=on}} | [[Miss Universe 1954]] | | |- style="background:#FFFACD;" | [[Miss USA 1955|1955]] | [[Carlene King Johnson]]{{cite news|title=Miss Vermont is Miss USA|date=1955-07-21|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=v6grAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Bf0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1764,3294385&dq=carlene-king-johnson&hl=en|page=16|last=Associated Press|publisher=The Nashua Telegraph}} | [[Rutland (city), Vermont|Rutland]] | [[Miss Vermont USA|Vermont]] | 22 | {{convert|5|ft|8|in|cm|abbr=on}} | Top 15 | | Died at age 35 due to complications of diabetes.{{cite news|title=Pageant officials search for missing beauty queens|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CNY0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=7VEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5440,5000808&dq=carlene-king-johnson&hl=en|publisher=The Bryan Times|date=1986-05-19}} |- |-style="background-color:gold; font-weight: bold" | [[Miss USA 1956|1956]] | [[Carol Morris]]{{cite news|title=Iowa Girl acclaimed as "Miss Universe"|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uGktAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JokFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1073,2320259&dq=miss-usa+carol-morris&hl=en|publisher=Tri City Herald|date=1956-07-22|page=2}} | [[Ottumwa, Iowa|Ottumwa]] | [[Miss Iowa USA|Iowa]] | 20 | {{convert|5|ft|7|in|cm|abbr=on}} | [[Miss Universe 1956]] | | |- | rowspan=2| [[Miss USA 1957|1957]] | [[Mary Leona Gage]] | [[Glen Burnie, Maryland|Glen Burnie]] | [[Miss Maryland USA|Maryland]] | 18 | {{convert|5|ft|9|in|cm|abbr=on}} | Top 15 (''Disqualified'') | [[File:Mary leona kaminer nee gage.jpg|100px]] |Gage was ejected from the competition when it was discovered she was married and the mother of two children.{{cite news|title=MANNERS & MORALS: Stairway to the Stars|publisher=Time|date=1957-07-29|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,825163,00.html}}

|1967{{efn|name=c|Was 2nd Runner-Up, and took over the Miss USA crown when the original winner won Miss Universe and the 1st Runner-Up declined the title}} |- |[[Iowa]] |1956{{efn|name=b}} |- page.title: List of convicts transported to Australia

revision.text:
The following is a list of notable '''[[convicts in Australia|convicts transported to Australia]]'''. [[Penal transportation]] to Australia began with the arrival of the [[First Fleet]] in 1788 and ended in 1868. Overall, approximately 165,000 convicts were transported to Australia.
{{compact ToC|x=|refs=yes|extlinks=yes}}
==Convicts==
===A=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> *[[Esther Abrahams]] (c. 1767–1846), English wife of [[George Johnston (British Marines officer)|George Johnston]], transported to New South Wales for theft
===B=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> [[File:George Barrington.jpg|thumb|upright|George Barrington]] [[File:William Buckley portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|William Buckley]] *[[Charlotte Badger]] (c. 1788–1816), English pirate, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Joseph Backler]] (1813–1895), English artist, transported to New South Wales for forgery *[[George Barrington]] (1755–1804), Irish author and socialite, transported to New South Wales for pickpocketing *[[John Baughan]] (1754–1797), English carpenter, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Andrew Bent]] (1790–1851), English printer and publisher, transported to New South Wales for burglary *[[Sarah Bellamy]] (1770 - 1843), English maid, servant and weaver, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[James Blackburn (architect)|James Blackburn]] (1803–1854), English architect and engineer, transported to Van Diemen's Land for forgery *[[William Bland]] (1789–1868), English politician and inventor, transported to Van Diemen's Land for manslaughter *[[Solomon Blay]] (1816–1897), English hangman, transported to Van Diemen's Land for forgery *[[James Bloodsworth]] (1759–1804), English builder, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Billy Blue]] (c. 1767–1834), Jamaican boatman, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Thomas Bock]] (1790–1855), English artist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for administering drugs to a young woman *[[Ruth Bowyer]] (c. 1761–1788), English First Fleeter, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Matthew Brady]] (1799–1826), English bushranger, transported to Van Diemen's Land *[[Richard Browne (artist)|Richard Browne]] (1776–1824), Irish artist, transported to New South Wales *[[Mary Bryant]] (1765–), Cornish escapee, transported to New South Wales for highway robbery *[[William Bryant (convict)|William Bryant]] (c. 1757–1791), Cornish escapee, transported to New South Wales for impersonating a Royal Navy seaman *[[William Buckley (convict)|William Buckley]] (1780–1856), English escapee, transported to New South Wales for possessing a roll of stolen cloth *[[Knud Bull]] (1811–1889), Norwegian artist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for forgery *[[Richard Burgess (murderer)|Richard Burgess]] (1829–1866), English bushranger, transported to New South Wales for highway robbery *[[Robert Francis Burns]] (1840-1883), Irish murderer, Transported to Western Australia for stealing
===C=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> *[[John Cadman (convict)|John Cadman]] (1772–1848), English publican, transported to New South Wales for horse theft *[[John Caesar]] (c. 1763–1796), Madagascan or West Indian bushranger, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Elizabeth Callaghan]] (1802-1852), Irish servant, transported to New South Wales for forgery<ref>{{cite web|last1=Watson|first1=Reg|title=John Batman: A Life ...|url=http://www.tasmaniantimes.com/index.php/article/john-batman|website=Tasmanian Times|accessdate=26 November 2015}}</ref> *[[John Casey (Australian convict)|John Casey]] (–1882), Irish rebel, transported to New South Wales for insurrection *[[Martin Cash]] (1808–1877), Irish bushranger, transported to New South Wales for shooting at a man *[[Denis Cashman]] (1842–1897), Irish Fenian, transported to Western Australia for treason *[[Margaret Catchpole]] (1762–1819), English adventuress and chronicler, transported to New South Wales for horse theft *[[Alfred Chopin]] (1846–1902), English photographer, transported to Western Australia for receiving stolen goods *[[William Clackson]] (c. 1799–), Scottish shoemaker and activist, transported to New South Wales for his role in the [[Radical War]] *[[Daniel Cooper (convict and merchant)|Daniel Cooper]], English businessman, transported to New South Wales for theft
===D=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> [[File:Dwyer.jpg|thumb|upright|Michael Dwyer]] *[[David Davies (Dai'r Cantwr)|David Davies]] (1812–1874), Welsh poet and rebel, transported to Van Diemen's Land for his role in the [[Rebecca Riots]] *[[Edward Davis (bushranger)|Edward Davis]] (1816–1841), Jewish bushranger, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[James Davis (escaped convict)|James Davis]] (1808–1889), Scottish escapee, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Jack Donahue]] (1804–1830), Irish bushranger, transported to New South Wales for intent to commit a felony *[[Michael Dwyer]] (1772–1825), Irish revolutionary, transported to New South Wales for his role in the [[Irish Rebellion of 1798]]
===E=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> *[[Edward Eagar]] (1787–1866), Irish lawyer and merchant, transported to New South Wales for forgery *[[Ralph Entwistle]] (c. 1805–1830), English bushranger, transported to New South Wales for stealing clothing *[[John Eyre (painter)|John Eyre]] (1771–), English artist, transported to New South Wales for housebreaking
===F=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> *[[William Field (Australian pastoralist)|William Field]] (1774–1837), English businessman, transported to Van Diemen's Land for receiving stolen goods *[[John Frost (Chartist)|John Frost]] (1784–1877), Welsh Chartist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for his role in the [[Newport Rising]] *[[Henry Fulton]] (1761–1840), Irish clergyman and schoolmaster, transported to New South Wales for his role in the [[Irish Rebellion of 1798]]
===G=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> [[File:Francis Greenway.jpg|thumb|upright|Francis Greenway]] *[[Joseph Gerrald]] (1763–1796), West Indian-born political reformer, transported to New South Wales for sedition *[[James Goodwin]] (c. 1800–c. 1835), English escapee and explorer, transported to Van Diemen's Land for theft *[[John Guard]] (c. 1791–1857), English whaler, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[William Buelow Gould]] (1801–1853), English artist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for theft *[[Francis Greenway]] (1777–1837), English architect, transported to New South Wales for forgery *[[William Henry Groom]] (1833–1901), English politician, transported to New South Wales for embezzlement
===H=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> *[[Laurence Hynes Halloran]] (1765–1831), Irish poet and schoolmaster, transported to New South Wales for forgery *[[Dorothy Handland]] (1706–), English rag dealer, transported to New South Wales for perjury<ref>{{cite book |last=Hughes |first=Robert |date=1986 |title=The Fatal Shore |url= |location=New York |publisher= Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. |page=73 |isbn= 0-394-75366-6}}</ref> *[[Henry Browne Hayes]] (1762–1832), Irish adventurer, transported to New South Wales for kidnapping *[[Daniel Herbert (convict)|Daniel Herbert]] (1802–1868), English artist and stonemason, transported to Van Diemen's Land for highway robbery *[[William Horton (publican)|William Horton]] (1817–1864), English publican, transported to New South Wales for larceny of a coat<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://communityheritage.net.au/william-horton|title=William Horton|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[National Trust of Australia]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="qhr">{{cite QHR|15613|Royal Bull's Head Inn|600838|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref> *[[George Howe (printer)|George Howe]] (1769–1821), English poet and printer, transported to New South Wales for shoplifting *[[Michael Howe (bushranger)|Michael Howe]] (1787–1818), English bushranger, transported to Van Diemen's Land for highway robbery *[[Ralph Hush]] (1779–1860), English farmer, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[William Hutchinson (superintendent)|William Hutchinson]] (1772–1846), English businessman, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Mary Hyde]] (1779–1864), English businesswoman, transported to New South Wales for theft
===I=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.-->

IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> [[File:Jørgen Jørgensen (Eckersberg).jpg|thumb|upright|Jørgen Jørgensen]] *[[Mark Jeffrey]] (1825–1903), English criminal, transported to New South Wales for burglary *Joseph Bolitho Johns (c. 1826–1900), English bushranger, also known as [[Moondyne Joe]], transported to Western Australia for theft *[[George Jones (bushranger)|George Jones]] (c. 1815-1844), English bushranger, native of [[Westminster]]. *[[William Jones (Chartist)|William Jones]] (1809–1873), Welsh Chartist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for his role in the [[Newport Rising]] *[[Jørgen Jørgensen]] (1780–1841), Danish adventurer, transported to Van Diemen's Land for theft

IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> *[[Solomon Levey]] (1794–1833), English merchant, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Simeon Lord]] (1771–1840), English businessman, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Tolpuddle Martyrs#Historical events|George Loveless]] (1797–1874), English labourer, transported to New South Wales as one of the [[Tolpuddle Martyrs]] *[[Nathaniel Lucas]] (1764–1818), English carpenter, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Joseph Lycett]] (1774–c. 1825), English artist, transported to New South Wales for forgery *[[John Lynch (serial killer)|John Lynch]] (1813–1842), Irish serial killer, transported to New South Wales for [[false pretense]] *[[Samuel Lyons]] (1791–1851), English businessman, transported to New South Wales for theft

IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> [[File:Thomas-Muir-bust-by-Alexander-Stoddart.jpg|thumb|upright|Thomas Muir]] *Francis MacNamara (c. 1810–1861), Irish poet, also known as [[Frank the Poet]], transported to Van Diemen's Land for larceny *[[John Martin (Young Irelander)|John Martin]] (1812–1875), Irish nationalist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for sedition *[[Terence MacManus]] (1811–1861), Irish nationalist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for treason *[[Maurice Margarot]] (1745–1815), English political reformer, transported to New South Wales for sedition *[[Valentine Marshall]] (1814–1874), English farmer, transported to Van Diemen's Land for his role in the [[Reform Act 1832|Reform Act Riots]] *[[Thomas Francis Meagher]] (1823–1867), Irish nationalist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for treason *[[George Mealmaker]] (1768–1808), Scottish political reformer, transported to New South Wales for sedition *[[John Mitchel]] (1815–1875), Irish nationalist and author, transported to Van Diemen's Land for treason *[[Enoch Moore (Loyalist turned rebel)|Enoch Moore]] (1779–1841), Canadian rebel, transported to Van Diemen's Land for his role in the [[Rebellions of 1837]] *[[Thomas Muir of Huntershill|Thomas Muir]] (1765–1799), Scottish political reformer and escapee, transported to New South Wales for sedition
===N=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. ===O=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.-->[[File:John Boyle O'Reilly cph.3a38519.jpg|thumb|253x253px|John Boyle O'Reilly]] *[[William Smith O'Brien]] (1803–1864), Irish nationalist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for treason *[[Kevin Izod O'Doherty]] (1823–1905), Irish nationalist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for treason *[[Patrick O'Donoghue (Young Irelander)|Patrick O'Donoghue]] (–1854), Irish nationalist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for treason *[[John Boyle O'Reilly]] (1844–1890), Irish Fenian, poet and author, transported to Western Australia for his role in the [[Fenian Rising]] *[[James Oatley]] (c. 1769–1839), English watchmaker, transported to New South Wales for theft
===P=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> *[[Thomas Fyshe Palmer]] (1747–1802), English political reformer, transported to New South Wales for sedition *[[Thomas Pamphlett]] (c. 1788–1838), English castaway, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Robert Pate]] (1819–1895), English army officer, transported to Van Diemen's Land for attacking [[Queen Victoria]] *[[Alexander Pearce]] (1790–1824), Irish escapee and cannibal, transported to Van Diemen's Land for theft *[[Joseph Potaski]] (1764–1824), Polish soldier, transported to Van Diemen's Land for theft
===Q=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.-->

[http://www.portrait.gov.au/magazines/36/fine-and-dandy "Fine and dandy"], [[National Portrait Gallery (Australia)|National Portrait Gallery]] (Portrait 27). Retrieved 5 October 2015.</ref> *[[James Ruse]] (c. 1759–1837), Cornish farmer, transported to New South Wales for housebreaking

IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> [[File:Solomon portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|Ikey Solomon]] *[[Joseph Samuel]] (c. 1780–1806), English escapee, transported to Van Diemen's Land for robbery *[[Henry Savery]] (1791–1842), English novelist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for forgery *[[Shoni Sguborfawr]] (1811–1858), Welsh rebel, transported to Norfolk Island for his role in the [[Rebecca Riots]] *[[Robert Sidaway]] (1758–1809), English philanthropist, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[William Skirving]] (c. 1745–1796), Scottish political reformer, transported to New South Wales for sedition *[[Ikey Solomon]] (c. 1787–1850), English criminal, transported to Van Diemen's Land for receiving stolen goods *[[James Squire]] (1754–1822), English brewer, transported to New South Wales for highway robbery *[[Elizabeth Steel]] (c. 1760–1795), English deaf person, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[Owen Suffolk]] (1829–), English poet and bushranger, transported to New South Wales for forgery
===T=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> *[[John Tawell]] (1784–1845), English chemist and murderer, transported to New South Wales for forgery *[[Samuel Terry]] (c. 1776–1838), English philanthropist, transported to New South Wales for theft *[[William Tucker (settler)|William Tucker]] (c. 1784–1817), English sealer, transported to New South Wales for theft
===U=== <!--DO NOT ADD ANY PEOPLE WITHOUT AN INLINE CITATION OF A RELIABLE, SECONDARY SOURCE. OTHER WIKIPEDIA ARTICLES CANNOT BE CITED AS SOURCES BECAUSE THAT IS CIRCULAR. IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.-->

IF THE OTHER ARTICLE HAS A CITATION, CITE THAT INSTEAD.--> [[File:Thomas Griffiths Wainewright.jpg|thumb|upright|Thomas Griffiths Wainewright]] *[[Thomas Griffiths Wainewright]] (1794–1847), English artist, journalist and alleged serial killer, transported to Van Diemen's Land for forgery *[[James Walsh (convict)|James Walsh]] ( 1833–1871), English artist, transported to Western Australia for theft and forgery *[[Thomas Watling]] (1762–c. 1814), Scottish artist, transported to New South Wales for forgery *[[William Westwood (bushranger)|William Westwood]] (c. 1830–1846), English bushranger, transported to New South Wales for stealing a coat *[[Joseph Wild]] (c. 1759–1847), English explorer, transported to New South Wales for burglary *[[Henry Wildman]] (1838–), English explorer, transported to Western Australia for burglary *[[Zephaniah Williams]] (1795–1874), Welsh Chartist, transported to Van Diemen's Land for his role in the [[Newport Rising]] *[[James Wilson (Irish nationalist)|James Wilson]] (1836–1921), Irish Fenian, transported to Western Australia for desertion and mutiny *[[Solomon Wiseman]] (1777–1838), English merchant and ferryman, transported to New South Wales for theft

page.title: List of winners and nominees of Hungarian comic awards

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=May 2011}} {{underlinked|date=November 2012}} }} This article is a '''list of winners and nominees of''' regular '''Hungarian comic awards''', sorted by awards, followed by category. == Alfabéta prize == Note: the years listed in the following tables marks the year the prize was awarded, the related comics were made in the preceding year. === Best Comic === (At least 20 pages long.) ==== Winners ==== {|| class="wikitable" |-valign="top" !'''Year''' !'''Translated title''' !'''Original title''' !'''Artist''' !'''Script''' !'''Publication title''' !'''Publisher''' |- |Year||Translated title||Original title||Artist||Script||Publication title||Publisher |- |2006||The Haven #1 - The caller||A Rév: A hívó||Róbert Odegnál||Róbert Odegnál||same as title||Vad virágok könyvműhely |- |2007||The bureaucrats||Bürokraták||Brazil (Szabolcs Tebeli)||Balázs Oroszlány, Áron Németh||Roham magazin||Roham |- |2008||The Gemini file - 1. - Hunting twins||A Gemini-jelentés 1: Ikervadászat||Attila Fazekas||Antal Bayer, based on Péter Korcsmáros' novel||A Gemini-jelentés 1: Ikervadászat||Képes kiadó |- |2009||Stroboscopa||Stroboscopa||Iván Kemenes||Iván baromfi||Róbert Vass||Róbert Vass||same as title||Nero Blanco Comix |} ==== Nominees ==== {|| class="wikitable" |-valign="top" !'''Year''' !'''Translated title''' !'''Original title''' !'''Artist''' yearly achievement. The prize was first awarded at the 100th anniversary of Ernő Zórád's birth with the contribution of the artist's family. * 2011: Attila Futaki == Kepregeny.net Audience Polls == Every year since 2006, Kepregeny.net gives place to the annual audience polls to record comic book fans' opinion on the preceding year's crop. These polls cover many topics, not only Hungarian comics, but also translated materials, journalists, etc. In the first two years the polls were held on the portal's forum, in 2008 it moved to its opening page.
Note: the year given in each poll refers to the year the comics were published (in contrary to the Alfabéta prize, where the year refers to date the prize was given.) === 2005 === {|| {{more citations needed|date=March 2014}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox spy | honorific_prefix = | name = Lona Cohen | honorific_suffix = | nickname = | image = Lona Cohen on Russian stamp.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Lona Cohen on Russian stamp | allegiance = [[USSR]] | service = | serviceyears = 1939–1961 (arrest) | rank = | operation = | award = [[Order of the Red Banner]], [[Order of Friendship of Peoples|Order of Friendship of Nations]] | codename1 = Helen Kroger | codename2 = | codename3 = | codename4 = | codename5 = | codename6 = | codename7 = | codename8 = | codename9 = | other = | birth_name = Leontine Theresa Petka | birth_date = {{Birth date|1913|1|11}} | birth_place = [[Adams, Massachusetts]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1992|12|23|1913|1|11}} | death_place = [[Moscow]] | nationality = American | religion = | residence = | parents = | spouse = [[Morris Cohen (spy)|Morris Cohen]] | children = | occupation = | alma_mater = | signature = | module = }} '''Lona Cohen''' {{cite news |last=Cornwell |first=Rupert |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/physicist-accused-of-being-spy-for-stalin-1321177.html |title=Physicist accused of being spy for Stalin |publisher=The Independent |date=February 26, 1996 |accessdate=October 22, 2014}} (January 11, 1913 – December 23, 1992), born '''Leontine Theresa Petka''', also known as '''Helen Kroger''', was an [[Americans|American]] [[espionage|spy]] for the [[Soviet Union]]. She was the wife of spy [[Morris Cohen (Soviet spy)|Morris Cohen]]. == Espionage == Lona Cohen was born '''Leontine Theresa Petka''' in [[Adams, Massachusetts]], the daughter of Polish [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] immigrants.[https://books.google.com/books?id=TrlRaHFHspsC&pg=PA207&dq=%22Lona+Petka+Cohen%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBYQ6AEwAWoVChMIqYettdTIyAIVCzw-Ch375Qfz] An American citizen, she was a member of the [[Communist Party USA]] and had been recruited into Soviet espionage in 1939 by her husband, [[Morris Cohen (Soviet spy)|Morris]]. She worked for Soviet case officers, including [[Anatoli Yatskov]], out of the New York ''[[Resident spy|rezidentura]]'' during [[World War II]].{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} After her husband was [[conscription|drafted]] in 1942, Cohen ran a network that included [[engineer]]s and [[technician]]s at munitions and [[aviation]] plants in the [[New York (state)|New York]] area. One of her sources smuggled a working model of a new machine gun out of a munitions plant. She worked at two defense plants, the Public Metal Company in [[New York City]] in 1941 and the Aircraft Screw Products plant on [[Long Island]] in 1943. She was a courier who picked up reports from [[Theodore Hall]], and a source [[Code name|cover name]]d "FOGEL" and "PERS" from the American secret [[atomic weapons]] project at [[Los Alamos National Laboratory#History|Los Alamos]], [[New Mexico]] and carried them to the Soviet consulate in New York, where a [[KGB]] sub-residency under a young engineer, [[Leonid R. Kvasnikov]], coordinated operations and dispatched intelligence to [[Moscow]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} After the defections of [[Elizabeth Bentley]] and [[Igor Gouzenko]], the Cohens ended contact with Soviet intelligence until 1949, at which time they began working with Col. [[Rudolph Abel]], a U.S. based [[illegal resident]]. After [[Klaus Fuchs]] was arrested in the [[United Kingdom]] in 1950, Cohen and her husband fled to [[Moscow]], where she received additional training as a [[radio]] operator and [[cipher]] clerk. In 1954, the pair resurfaced in [[London]] under the names Helen and Peter Kroger with [[New Zealand]] [[passport]]s. They set up an antiquarian book business which was cover for their activities of running the London Illegal Rezidentura. [[Gordon Lonsdale]] worked with them as part of the [[Portland Spy Ring]]. While in London, the Cohens were friends with Frank and Nora Doel. [[Frank Doel]] is the bookseller whose correspondence with the author [[Helene Hanff]] became the bestseller, ''[[84 Charing Cross Road]]''. In her follow-up book, ''The Duchess of Bloomsbury Street'', Hanff reported an anecdote told her by Nora Doel.{{cite book |last=Hanff |first=Helene |title=The Duchess of Bloomsbury Street |year=1976 |publisher=Avon |isbn=0-380-00634-0}} One [[New Year's Eve]], the Doels gave a party at which Lona Cohen (aka Helen Kroger):
arrived looking very exotic in a long black evening dress. 'Helen, you look like a Russian spy!' said Nora. And Helen laughed and Peter laughed and a few months later Nora picked up the morning paper and discovered that Helen and Peter Kruger ''were'' Russian spies.
== Imprisonment == [[File:Cranley Drive, Ruislip - geograph.org.uk - 306570.jpg|thumb|right|Cohen house in [[Ruislip]], found full of transmitting equipment]] In the basement of their house, at 45 Cranley Drive, Ruislip, situated not far from the military airfield of [[Northolt]], they set up a high speed radio transmitter and began sending Moscow "information of special importance". In January 1961, they were arrested for espionage, and in March, she received a sentence of 20 years while her husband got 25 years, of which they served only eight, until in 1969, the two were finally exchanged with the Soviet Union for a British subject called [[Gerald Brooke]]. Before being taken in custody, Mrs. Kroger had asked permission to stoke up the boiler. Before she could do so, Detective Superintendent Smith, a veteran "spy catcher" who was in charge of the arrest, insisted on checking her handbag first. It was found to contain microdots, the photographic reduction of documents, in order to make them small enough to be smuggled out of the country more easily. ==Personal and death== [[File:Morris Cohen on Russian stamp.jpg|thumb|right|[[Morris Cohen (spy)|Morris Cohen]] on Russian stamp]] In 1941, Cohen married [[Morris Cohen (spy)|Morris Cohen]], who recruited her to his espionage activities. Cohen died in Moscow on December 23, 1992. == Awards == Lona Cohen was awarded the [[Order of the Red Banner]] and [[Order of Friendship of Peoples|Order of Friendship of Nations]] by the Soviet Union. ==Legacy== Once in [[Moscow]], the Cohens continued training colleagues for illegal intelligence operations.''Deep Cover: My Secret Life and Tangled Allegiances as a KGB Spy in America'', by Jack Barsky with Cindy Coloma, Carol Stream, IL: Tyndale Momentum. Chapter 16 is entirely about a KGB agent's memoir of being trained by the Cohen's in Moscow in the late 1970s. In 1983, the British playwright [[Hugh Whitemore]] dramatized the case as ''[[Pack of Lies]]'', which was performed in London's [[West End theatre]] district starring [[Judi Dench]] and [[Michael Williams (actor)|Michael Williams]]. It played on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] for 3½ months in 1985, for which [[Rosemary Harris]] won the best actress [[Tony award]] for her portrayal of the British neighbor of the Cohens/Krogers. It was made into a TV movie starring [[Ellen Burstyn]], [[Alan Bates]], [[Teri Garr]] and [[Daniel Benzali]] (as "Peter Schaefer," i.e., "Peter Kroger," i.e., Morris Cohen) which aired in the U.S. on [[CBS]] in 1987. The plot centered on the neighbors (and seeming friends) whose house was used as a base from which the security services could spy on the Cohens, and the way [[paranoia]], suspicion and betrayal gradually destroyed their lives during that time. The Cohens' cover as antiquarian book dealers Peter and Helen Kroger is mentioned in [[Helene Hanff]]'s ''The Duchess of Bloomsbury Street'' because they were friends of London book dealer [[Frank Doel]], recipient of the letters and book orders that inspired the bestseller ''[[84 Charing Cross Road]]''. == References == {{reflist}} == External sources == {{more footnotes|date=October 2014}} *{{cite book |first1=Joseph |last1=Albright |first2=Marcia |last2=Kunstel |title=Bombshell: The Secret Story of America's Unknown Atomic Spy Conspiracy |location=New York |publisher=Times Books |year=1997 |pages=244–253}} *{{cite book |first1=John Earl |last=Haynes |authorlink1=John Earl Haynes |first2=Harvey |last2=Klehr |authorlink2=Harvey Klehr |title=Venona: Decoding Soviet Espionage in America |location=New Haven |publisher=[[Yale University Press]] |year=1999 |pages=316, 317–319, 320, 321, 334 |isbn=0-300-08462-5}} *{{cite book |author=Russian Federal Foreign Intelligence Service |title=Veterany vneshnei razvedki Rosii (Veterans of Russian foreign intelligence service) |location=Moscow |publisher=Russian Federal Foreign Intelligence Service |year=1995}} *{{cite book |first1=Richard C.S. |last1=Trahair |first2=Robert |last2=Miller |title=Encyclopedia of Cold War Espionage, Spies, and Secret Operations |location=New York |publisher=Enigma Books |year=2009 |isbn=978-1-929631-75-9}} *{{cite book |first=Rebecca |last=West |title=The New Meaning of Treason |location=New York |publisher=Viking |year=1964 |pages=281–288}} *Carr, Barnes (2016) ''Operation Whisper; The Capture of Soviet Spies Morris and Lorna Cohen'' ForeEdge Books/ UPNE [http://www.upne.com/1611688092.html] {{ISBN|9781611688092}} *{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/march/13/newsid_4059000/4059209.stm |author=BBC |title=On This Day: 13 March 1961: Five Britons accused of spying for Moscow}} Includes a video news report on the Krogers/Cohens' return to the Soviet Union and an interview with former [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[George Brown, Baron George-Brown|George Brown]] over the issues. *{{cite web |last=Chervonnaya |first=Svetlana |authorlink=Svetlana Chervonnaya |url=https://www.pbs.org/redfiles/kgb/deep/interv/k_int_svetlana_chervonnaya.htm |publisher=PBS |title=Red Files: Secret Victories of the KGB - Svetlana Chervonnaya Interview}} *{{cite web |url=http://vault.fbi.gov/Morris%20and%20Linda%20Cohen/Morris%20and%20Lona%20Cohen%20Part%201%20of%204 |author=Federal Bureau of Investigation |title=Subject: Morris and Lona Cohen, File Number: 100-406659}} *[http://svr.gov.ru Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR)] {{ru icon}} {{portal|Biography|World War II|Cold War}} {{Soviet Spies}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cohen, Lona}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:1992 deaths]] [[Category:American activists]] [[Category:American communists]] [[Category:American defectors to the Soviet Union]] [[Category:American people convicted of spying for the Soviet Union]] [[Category:American people in the Venona papers]] [[Category:Burials at Kuntsevo Cemetery]] [[Category:Female wartime spies]] [[Category:Heroes of the Russian Federation]] [[Category:Manhattan Project people]] [[Category:People from Adams, Massachusetts]] [[Category:People from New York City]] [[Category:Portland Spy Ring]] [[Category:American women in World War II]] [[Category:World War II spies for the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Place of death missing]]

= 2,500 |languages = [[Languages of Malaysia]] |rels = [[Religion in Malaysia]] }} '''Malaysians''' are the people who are identified with the country of [[Malaysia]], its citizens and their descendants worldwide. This connection may be residential, legal, historical, or cultural. For most Malaysians, several (frequently all) of those types of connections exist and are the source(s) of their being considered Malaysians. Although citizens make up the majority of Malaysians, non-citizen residents and overseas Malaysians may also claim a Malaysian identity.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2015/05/03/Survey-Most-prefer-to-be-known-as-Msian/|title=Survey: Most prefer to be known as Malaysian|author1=Neville Spykerman|author2=Michelle Tam|author3=Victoria Brown|publisher=The Star|date=3 May 2015|accessdate=3 May 2015}} The country is home to people of various [[Nationality|national]], [[Ethnic group|ethnic]] and religious origins. As a result, many Malaysians do not equate their [[nationality]] with [[ethnicity]], but with [[citizenship]] and [[allegiance]] to Malaysia. Majority of the population, however, belong to several clearly defined [[ethnolinguistic]] groups within the country with their own distinct cultures and traditions: [[Malays (ethnic group)|Malays]], [[Orang Asli]] (aboriginal population), [[Malaysian Chinese]] (primarily [[Han Chinese]]), [[Malaysian Indians]] (primarily [[Tamils]]). Malays themselves are the source of the name ''Malaysia'' ("land of Malays") as they traditionally formed the majority during the British rule. The majority of the non-Malay and non-aboriginal population in modern Malaysia is made up of immigrants and their descendants. Following the initial period of Portuguese, Dutch and then significantly longer British colonization, different waves (or peaks) of immigration and settlement of non-[[aboriginal peoples]] took place over the course of nearly five centuries and continue today. [[Federation of Malaya Independence Act 1957|Malayan independence]] from [[United Kingdom]] in 1957 grew gradually over the course of latter part of the 20th century since the formation of the [[Federation of Malaya]] in 1948 (excluding [[Crown Colony of Singapore]], [[Crown Colony of North Borneo]] and [[Crown Colony of Sarawak]]). [[World War II]] in particular gave rise to a desire amongst Malayans to have their country recognised as a fully-fledged sovereign state with a distinct citizenship. ==Population== {{main|Demographics of Malaysia}} As of 2010, Malaysians make up 0.4% of the [[world population|world's total population]], having relied upon immigration for population growth and social development. Approximately 30% of current Malaysians are first- or second-generation immigrants, and 20 percent of Malaysian residents in the 2000s were not born in Malaysian soil. It is estimated, by 2031, nearly one-half of Malaysians above the age of 15 will be [[foreign born]] or have one foreign born parent. [[Bumiputera (Malaysia)|Bumiputera]], according to the [https://web.archive.org/web/20150301154300/http://www.statistics.gov.my/portal/download_Population/files/census2010/Taburan_Penduduk_dan_Ciri-ciri_Asas_Demografi.pdf 2010 Malaysian Census], numbered at 17,523,508 or 61.85% of the country's 28,334,135 population. ===Immigration=== {{main|Immigration to Malaysia}} ===Citizenship and diaspora=== {{main|Malaysian nationality law|Malaysian diaspora}} ===Ethnic ancestry=== {{main|Ethnic origins of people in Malaysia}} ===Ethnic groups and citizenship=== Classification of [[2010 Malaysian Census|2010 Census]] ethnic group is as set by Inter-Agency Technical Committee (IATC) in Appendix 1. IATC is a committee formed to co-ordinate and monitor the implementation and use of standardised codes, classifications and definitions used by the Department of Statistics, Malaysia and other government agencies. For the purpose of tabulation and analysis, as well as taking into account the diverse ethnic group in Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, Federal Territory of Labuan and Sarawak, major ethnic groups according to region as follows: {| class=wikitable |- !
