[[File:Shaka at birth basin.JPG|thumb|right|300px|[[Gautama Buddha|Shaka]] [[Gautama Buddha#Conception and birth|at Birth]] and [[Wiktionary:lustration|lustration]] basin; gilt bronze; [[Nara period]]; height of figure {{convert|47.5|cm|ftin}}; diameter of basin {{convert|89.2|cm|ftin}}; [[National Treasures of Japan|National Treasures]]<ref name="Forms">{{cite book |title=Transmitting the Forms of Divinity: Early Buddhist Art from Korea and Japan |author=Washizuka Hiromitsu (''et al.'') |publisher=[[Japan Society (New York)|Japan Society]] |year=2003 |isbn=0913304549 |pages=292f}}</ref>]]
The {{nihongo|standing bronze statue of '''[[Gautama Buddha|Shaka]] [[Gautama Buddha#Conception and birth|at Birth]]'''|銅造誕生釈迦仏立像|dōzō tanjō Shaka butsu ryūzō}} at '''[[Tōdai-ji]]''' in the city of [[Nara, Nara|Nara]] in Japan, along with the [[Wiktionary:lustration|lustration]] basin in which the image stands, are of the type used in the [[Hanamatsuri|annual celebrations]] of the [[Gautama#Conception and birth|Buddha's birth]] on 8 April. The statue and its basin date to the [[Nara period]] and have been [[Cultural Properties of Japan|designated]] [[National Treasures of Japan|National Treasures]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kunishitei.bunka.go.jp/bsys/maindetails.asp?register_id=201&item_id=216 |title=銅造誕生釈迦仏立像 |trans-title=Standing bronze statue of Shaka at Birth |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://kunishitei.bunka.go.jp/bsys/maindetails.asp?register_id=201&item_id=217 |title=銅造灌仏盤 |trans-title=Bronze kanbutsuban |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref>
==Subject== The birth of Shaka, the historical Buddha ([[Sanskrit]]: [[Gautama|Siddhārtha Gautama]] or Śākyamuni), is one of the eight major events in the life of the Buddha that formed a popular subject for artistic representation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aisf.or.jp/~jaanus/deta/s/shakahassou.htm |title=Shaka hassou |publisher=[[Japanese Architecture and Art Net Users System]] |accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aisf.or.jp/~jaanus/deta/s/shaka.htm |title=Shaka |publisher=[[Japanese Architecture and Art Net Users System]] |accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> While [[Maya (mother of Buddha)|Māyā]] was walking in the [[Lumbini|Lumbinī gardens]] and had stopped to pick flowers, the Buddha is said to have emerged from her right side.<ref name="Forms"/><ref name="GreatAge"/> According to the ''Dīrghāgama Sūtra'', the young prince immediately took seven steps in the four directions and declared "in the Heavens and on Earth, only I am the Venerable One".<ref group="note">天上天下唯我独尊 (''tenjō tenga yuiga dokuson''); as a modern idiom these words are sometimes used to satirize self-aggrandizing conceit</ref><ref name="Flammarion">{{cite book |title=Buddhism: Flammarion Iconographic Guides |author=Frédéric, Louis |publisher=[[Groupe Flammarion|Flammarion]] |year=1995 |isbn=2080135589 |pages=87–9, 303–4}}</ref><ref name="Kanbutsue"/> The ''Lalitavistara'' relates that the infant was then bathed by two [[nāga]], Nanda and Upananda, serpent deities or [[Dragon Kings]].<ref name="Kanbutsue"/><ref name="Eastern"/><ref name="DeVisser">{{cite book |title=Ancient Buddhism in Japan I |author=de Visser, M. W |year=1935 |publisher=[[Brill Publishers|Brill]] |pages=45–57}}</ref>
The ''Sutra on the meritorious action of bathing the Buddha's image'' was translated into Chinese in 710.<ref name="DeVisser"/> Reenacting the legend of the Buddha's birth, the annual rite known as ''kanbutsu-e'' ("rite of sprinkling the Buddha", more popularly ''[[Buddha’s Birthday#Japan 2|hana matsuri]]'' or "flower festival") sees the bathing of small Buddha statues amidst garlands of flowers.<ref name="Kanbutsue">{{cite web |url=http://www.aisf.or.jp/~jaanus/deta/k/kanbutsue.htm |title=Kanbutsu-e |publisher=[[Japanese Architecture and Art Net Users System]] |accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Living Buddhist Statues in Early Medieval and Modern Japan |author=Horton, Sarah J |publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]] |year=2007 |isbn=9781403964205 |pages=22–6}}</ref> Perfumed water was once used but, since the nineteenth century, this has generally been replaced by sweet [[hydrangea]] tea known as ''amacha''.<ref group="note">''Amacha'' was also used to sweeten beverages, before the introduction of sugar to Japan in the seventeenth century; mixed with ink it is used to write on paper that is the glued to the wall of houses to ward off insects</ref><ref name="Forms"/><ref name="Flammarion"/> Another variant sees the image repeatedly wiped with a silk cloth rather than [[Anointing|anointed]].<ref name="GreatAge">{{cite book |title=The Great Age of Japanese Buddhist Sculpture, AD 600-1300 |author1=Nishikawa Kyōtarō |author2=Sano, Emily J |publisher=[[Japan Society (New York)|Japan Society]] |year=1983 |isbn=0912804084 |pages=60–1}}</ref>
Celebrations of the Buddha's birth have been staged in Japan on the eighth day of the fourth month since [[Empress Suiko]] ordered that vegetarian feasts should be held in all the temples in 606.<ref name="DeVisser"/> ''Kanbutsu-e'' or "sprinkling" ceremonies are known to have been held at the [[Heian Palace|Seiryōden]], led by a priest from [[Gangō-ji]], in 840 and the ''[[Engi shiki]]'' lists the utensils used at these Palace ceremonies.<ref name="DeVisser"/> Earlier [[List of Japanese temple records|temple records]] and inventories of their treasures list ''kanbutsuzō'' or "images for sprinkling" at [[Hōryū-ji]] and [[Daian-ji]], and early surviving examples include one dating to the [[Asuka period]] at {{nihongo|Shōgen-ji|正眼寺}} in [[Aichi Prefecture]] ([[Important Cultural Properties of Japan|Important Cultural Property]]).<ref name="DeVisser"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://kunishitei.bunka.go.jp/bsys/maindetails.asp?register_id=201&item_id=5091 |title=銅造誕生釈迦仏立像 |trans-title=Standing bronze statue of Shaka at Birth |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref> This example at [[Tōdai-ji]] is generally dated to the 750s.<ref name="Forms"/><ref name="Eastern"/>
At Tōdai-ji today, a {{nihongo|temporary flower hall|花御堂|hanamidō}} is erected each year before the [[Main Hall (Japanese Buddhism)|Daibutsuden]] (Great Buddha Hall).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.todaiji.or.jp/contents/function/04busyoue.html |title=仏生会 |trans-title=Rites for the Buddha's Birth (Bussho-e) |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Tōdai-ji]] |accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> This National Treasure Shaka at Birth was still used in the ceremony when [[Langdon Warner]] was writing in the late 1950s and indeed as late as the 1980s.<ref name="Eastern">{{cite book |title=The Great Eastern Temple: Treasures of Japanese Buddhist Art from Todai-ji |author=Mino Yutaka |publisher=[[Art Institute of Chicago]] |year=1986 |isbn=0253326346 |pages=77f}}</ref><ref name="Warner">{{cite book |title=Japanese Sculpture of the Tempyo Period: Masterpieces of the Eighth Century |author=[[Langdon Warner|Warner, Langdon]] |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]] |year=1964 |pages=92f}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Nara Buddhist Art: Todai-ji |author=Kobayashi Takeshi |publisher=[[Weatherhill]] |year=1975 |isbn=0834810212 |pages=56, 60}}</ref> More recently it has been replaced with a copy.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9Vvd-66zhwM |title=奈良 東大寺所蔵 誕生釈迦仏 |trans-title=Nara - Todaiji Collection - Shaka at Birth |language=Japanese |publisher=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref>
==Statue== Evoking the legend of his birth, the statue of the infant Buddha has its right arm raised, pointing to heaven, and left arm pendant, pointing to the earth; he is bare chested and wears a skirt.<ref name="Forms"/> The elongated earlobes and spiral-shaped curls of hear, resembling snail-shells, are among the [[Physical characteristics of the Buddha#The 80 secondary characteristics|eighty secondary physical characteristics of the Buddha]].<ref name="GreatAge"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aisf.or.jp/~jaanus/deta/r/rahotsu.htm |title=Rahotsu |publisher=[[Japanese Architecture and Art Net Users System]] |accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> The deep ridges on both body and arms "emphasize the fleshiness" of the smiling child's body.<ref name="GreatAge"/> The soft, rounded, "sweet-faced" features of the young Buddha have been likened to those of the celestial musicians on the roughly contemporary octagonal lantern erected in front of the Tōdai-ji [[Main Hall (Japanese Buddhism)|Daibutsuden]].<ref name="Forms"/> The original pedestal on which the image stands has been lost and replaced with a small wooden base [[Wood carving|carved]] with [[Padma (attribute)|lotus]] petals.<ref name="Eastern"/>
==Basin== Like the statue, the basin or ''kanbutsuban'' is the largest of its type known.<ref name="Kanbutsue"/><ref name="Eastern"/> The exterior has incised images of human figures, animals real and imaginary, birds, and butterflies, set against a landscape of flowers, grasses, shrubs, trees, mountain peaks, clouds, and [[Tō|pagodas]].<ref name="Eastern"/><ref name="Warner"/> Images of hermits with banners riding on birds, barbarians in foreign garb astride [[Chinese lion]]s, and hunters chasing tigers are similar to motifs found on metalwork in Tōdai-ji's celebrated repository the [[Shōsōin]].<ref name="Forms"/><ref name="GreatAge"/><ref name="Eastern"/> Much of this decoration is secular rather than Buddhist in inspiration.<ref name="GreatAge"/> Like the statue, the basin shows the influence of contemporary [[Tang dynasty|Tang]] China.<ref name="Forms"/><ref name="GreatAge"/>
==Technology== Both statue and basin are of [[Gilding|gilt]] [[bronze]], [[Casting (metalworking)|cast]] using the [[Lost-wax casting|lost-wax method]].<ref name="GreatAge"/> The statue was cast in one piece, other than for the right forearm which is a [[Conservation Techniques for Cultural Properties|restoration]]; the join is clearly visible.<ref name="GreatAge"/><ref name="Eastern"/> Pieces of the clay core were left inside after casting.<ref name="Eastern"/> The decorative motifs on the outside of the basin were [[engraved]] and the background of dots hammered with a [[Burin (engraving)|burin]] in the technique known as {{nihongo|"fish-[[roe]]"|魚々子|nanako}}.<ref name="Eastern"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aisf.or.jp/~jaanus/deta/n/nanako.htm |title=Nanako |publisher=[[Japanese Architecture and Art Net Users System]] |accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> Both statue and bowl are recognized as masterpieces of eighth-century metalwork.<ref name="Kanbutsue"/>
==See also== * [[List of National Treasures of Japan (sculptures)]] * [[Hanamatsuri]] * [[Vesak]] * [[Tōdai-ji]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|group=note}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{coord missing|Japan}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Shaka at Birth (Todai-ji)}} [[Category:National Treasures of Japan]] [[Category:Japanese sculpture]] [[Category:Buddhist sculpture]] [[Category:Bronze sculptures in Japan]] [[Category:Gautama Buddha]]

{{notability|bio|date=December 2013}}
'''Steven Kolb''' is president and chief executive officer of the [[Council of Fashion Designers of America]] (CFDA), a group of over 500 American fashion womenswear, menswear, jewelry, and accessories designers. He holds a Masters in Public Administration from [[New York University]] and an honorary doctorate of the Arts from Kendall College of Art and Design at [[Ferris State University]] in Grand Rapids, Michigan.[http://www.ferris.edu/HTMLS/news/archive/2014/may/kolb.htm] The [[Business of Fashion]] ranks Kolb as one of 500 people shaping the global fashion industry. [http://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/steven-kolb]. In 2018, he was named to the Out100 list, a celebration of the most influential LGBTQ people of the year. [[https://www.out.com/out-exclusives/2018/11/14/out100-2018#slide-50]].
Kolb manages the CFDA's membership, trade association activities, and longstanding philanthropic initiatives such as Fashion Targets Breast Cancer,<ref>[http://fashiontargetsbreastcancer.com/ Fashion Targets Breast Cancer]</ref> which raises public awareness and funds for breast cancer research in the U.S. and internationally. Furthermore, he has overseen raising funds for natural disasters such as Fashion for Sandy,<ref>[http://cfda.com/the-latest/fashion-for-sandy-relief-raises-1-7-million Fashion for Sandy]</ref> which raised funds after Hurricane Sandy and for HIV/AIDS through initiatives such as 7th on Sale.
Kolb works directly with CFDA Board Chair [[Diane von Furstenberg]] and the Board of Directors, which is composed of America's foremost designers, such as [[Vera Wang]], [[Ralph Lauren]], [[Michael Kors]], [[Ashley Olsen]], [[Prabal Gurung]], and Deborah Lloyd.<ref>[http://cfda.com/about/organization CFDA Board of Directors]</ref>
One of Kolb's largest contributions to American fashion has been his leadership role in cultivating the next wave of emerging American fashion talent through programs such as the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund<ref>[http://cfda.com/programs/the-cfdavogue-fashion-fund CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund]</ref> (CVFF). Kolb serves as a judge for CVFF and was featured on "The Fashion Fund," an original unscripted series documenting CVFF. Other CFDA program's where he sits on the selection committee include the Elaine Gold Launch Pad in partnership with the Accessories Council [https://wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-scoops/cfda-accessories-council-kick-off-elaine-gold-launchpad-round-two-1202685008/] and the CFDA/Lexus Fashion Initiative supporting sustainable fashion practices. He also serves as a judge for the International Woolmark Prize and the H&M Foundation Global Change Award.
Kolb has helped build the annual CFDA Fashion Awards to become the preeminent spotlight on American fashion, even being called the Oscars of Fashion.<ref>[http://www.wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-scoops/coffee-break-7253642 CNN WWD]</ref> The CFDA Fashion Awards red carpet and show are streamed on CFDA's Facebook page with over 4 million viewers watching in 2018.
Under his direction, the CFDA worked with the Boston Consulting group to conduct an extensive study to evaluate the purpose of New York Fashion Week. The intent of the study was to question the status quo of fashion week and stimulate a dialogue in the American fashion industry.<ref>[http://www.vogue.com/13409856/cfda-future-of-nyfw-study/]</ref> As the result of the study many designers shifted to See Now Buy Now collections and outside the traditional September and February fashion week schedules.
Kolb has also worked to establish the Strategic Partnerships Group (SPG) at the CFDA. This group works to strategically align corporate partners with the CFDA's members, in an effort to leverage and add value to both the partner and the designer, respectively. [[Charlotte Ronson]] and [[Stacey Bendet]] of Alice & Olivia created limited-edition items for [[Starbucks]] as a result of one of these symbiotic partner and designer relationships.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2013/06/04/living/gallery/cfda-fashion-awards/ CNN Living]</ref> Other partnerships include the NFL's Super Bowl, Cartoon Network and Pokémon.
Furthermore, Kolb helped pave the way for the CFDA's Health Initiative, which was formed to address the overwhelming concern about whether some models are unhealthily thin, and how to implement best practices in such cases. In 2018, the Health Initiative was expand to the Initiative on Heath, Safety and Diversity addressing harassment and assault and the need for more diverse casting. Civic responsibility became a core pillar of CFDA's work with Kolb leading campaigns with Planned Parenthood, ACLU and immigration reform with FWD.US. [https://wwd.com/business-news/business-features/cfda-fwd-immigration-report-1202672540/] In addition, under his direction CFDA produced a study with Glamour Magazine called "The Glass Runway" looking at the gender inequalities in the fashion industry and offering actionable steps for improvement. [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/20/fashion/glass-runway-no-female-ceos.html]
Kolb has helped develop the Fashion Manufacturing Initiative,<ref>[http://cfda.com/programs/the-fashion-manufacturing-initiative Fashion Manufacturing Initiative]</ref> which is an investment fund to help revitalize [[New York City]]'s garment industry. The program offers matching financial grants to New York City's fashion manufacturing production facilities looking to grow and sustain their business by acquiring of innovative equipment, expanding their services, training workers, and creating professional development programming. He served on the Manhattan Borough President's working group to define new initiatives to support mid-town Manhattan production. Kolb also works tirelessly to keep a designer's original designs intact through efforts such as the Innovative Design Protection and Piracy Prevention Act.
A major accomplishment, Kolb successfully led CFDA's effort to acquire the Fashion Calendar—the official schedule of fashion events and shows in New York, including New York Fashion Week. [http://fashionweekdaily.com/the-cfda-acquires-ruth-finleys-fashion-calendar/] Moreover, Kolb works with international counterparts to manage the global fashion week schedule and he spearheaded the creation of the New York Fashion Week logo and brand. In July 2015, under Kolb's leadership, New York Fashion Week: Men's launched creating a stand-alone fashion week for American menswear that aligns with the men's market. [http://www.complex.com/style/2015/07/creation-of-new-york-fashion-week-men]
==Prior work== Kolb's background was also in the non-profit sector, but focused on raising funds for HIV and [[AIDS]] and [[cancer]]. He began his career at the American Cancer Society in New Jersey. While working as the deputy director at the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS [[Diffa.org|DIFFA]] he managed a network of chapter affiliates and raised millions of dollars through events like Dining by Design and caused related marketing programs like the Gift of Hope. He is the founding executive director of MTV's Staying Alive Foundation where is set up the organization as a 501(c)3 and established an international grant making program for HIV/AIDS prevention and education for youth.
==Personal life== On December 27, 2012 Kolb married longtime partner Jason Inkpen in New York City. He has a collection of owls.<ref>[http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/07/collect-call-steven-kolbs-owls/?_r=0 New York Times Magazine]</ref> His rescue dog, Donna, a chihuahua terrier mix has her own Instagram account @offcialdonnathedog . His social media is Instagram: @stevenkolb Twitter: @Stevenkolb Kolb practices [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The CFDA's Steven Kolb discusses the new men's fashion week, American fashion and Instagram|url=http://www.buro247.com/me/fashion/insiders/cfda-steven-kolb-interview.html|website=Buro 24/7|accessdate=19 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bfLDgYbE?url=http://www.buro247.com/me/fashion/insiders/cfda-steven-kolb-interview.html|archivedate=19 September 2015|date=11 June 2015|quote=About a year ago I started transcendental meditation, and I find it to be fulfilling.|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * https://wwd.com/fashion-news/designer-luxury/the-cfdas-stephen-kolb-sees-an-industry-trying-new-things-1202781936/ * https://models.com/mdx/in-discussion-with-cfdas-steven-kolb/ * https://www.teenvogue.com/story/fashion-careers-advice-cfda-president-steven-kolb-interview * https://www.forbes.com/sites/josephdeacetis/2017/07/26/speaking-with-steven-kolb-cfda-president-and-ceo/ * http://fashionista.com/2015/07/steven-kolb-career * http://gotham-magazine.com/people-post/cfda-ceo-steven-kolb-new-york-first-mens-fashion-week * http://fashionista.com/2013/06/the-cfdas-steven-kolb-gives-us-a-tour-through-his-owl-filled-office-opens-up-about-past-awards-shows/ * http://www.vanityfair.com/online/daily/2013/08/cfda-steven-kolb-fashion-industry * http://nymag.com/thecut/2013/01/cfda-is-like-calling-1-800-fashion-help.html * http://www.businessoffashion.com/2011/10/ceo-talk-steven-kolb-chief-executive-officer-council-of-fashion-designers-of-america.html * https://archive.is/20140127165124/http://www.avenuemagazine.com/2011/09/steven-kolb-at-the-heart-of-fashion/ * http://www.refinery29.com/cfda-ceo-steven-kolb-inverview * http://www.vanityfair.com/online/daily/2013/08/cfda-steven-kolb-fashion-industry * http://nymag.com/thecut/2013/09/steven-kolb-on-citibiking-through-fashion-week.html * https://nypost.com/2016/06/06/inside-the-stylish-life-of-cfda-boss-steven-kolb/ * http://coveteur.com/2016/06/06/steven-kolb-president-ceo-cfda-apartment/

'''Tadeusz Romuald Jeziorowski''' (born in 1944) is a Polish [[historian]] and writer specialising in [[weaponry]], [[uniforms]] and [[orders]].
A graduate of the [[Kraków]] High School of Fine Arts, he earned an MA in Connoisseurship Studies from the Faculty of the Fine Arts in [[Nicolaus Copernicus University in Toruń]]. Since 1968 he worked in the [[Military Museum of Wielkopolska]] (part of the [[National Museum, Poznań]]). He was its head since 1973, and also had the title of [[curator]] between 1991 and 2012.
He is a member of the team for addressing and providing opinions on matters related to [[Order (distinction)|orders and distinctions]], [[heraldry]] and [[vexillology]] in the [[President of Poland|Presidential Office of the Republic of Poland]] and in the Heraldic Commission at the [[Ministry of Interior and Administration (Poland)|Ministry of the Interior and Administration]].
He is also a part of the Association of Old Arms and Uniforms Amateurs ([[:pl:Stowarzyszenie Miłośników Dawnej Broni i Barwy|Stowarzyszenie Miłośników Dawnej Broni i Barwy]]), the Polish Heraldic Society ([[:pl:Polskie Towarzystwo Heraldyczne|Polskie Towarzystwo Heraldyczne]]), German BDOS ([[:de:Deutsche Gesellschaft für Ordenskunde|Deutsche Gesellschaft für Ordenskunde]] e. V.); founder and honorary president of the Society of Former Soldiers and Friends of the 15th Regiment of Poznań Lancers (Towarzystwo b. Żołnierzy i Przyjaciół 15. Pułku Ułanów Poznańskich).<ref name=cn/>
He was awarded Knight's and Officer’s Cross of the [[Order of Polonia Restituta|Order of the Rebirth of Poland]] (2008<ref>[http://prawo.sejm.gov.pl/isap.nsf/DocDetails.xsp?id=WMP20090270356 Postanowienie Prezydenta Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej z dnia 22 października 2008 r. o nadaniu orderów (M.P. z 2009 r. Nr 27, poz. 356)]</ref> and 2017<ref>[http://prawo.sejm.gov.pl/isap.nsf/DocDetails.xsp?id=WMP20180000052 Postanowienie Prezydenta Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej z dnia 23 października 2017 r. o nadaniu orderów (M.P. z 2018 r., poz. 52)]</ref>).
Author of the first Polish monograph of the [[pallasch]] [[sword]]: ''Brać się do pałasza!'', Poznań 2001, of a text on uniforms ''Mundury wojewódzkie Rzeczypospolitej Obojga Narodów'' (with A. Jeziorkowski, illustrations) Warszawa 1992, and of a catalogue of the collection of the Military Museum of Wielkopolska ''[[Virtuti Militari|Order Wojenny Virtuti Militari]]'' (with J. Łuczak) Poznań 1993, and of a monograph of the orders during [[napoleonic era]] ''Ordery napoleońskie. Ordery generałów polskich w epoce napoleońskiej'' (with R. Morawski, illustrations) Warszawa 2018.
He has written numerous articles on the above topics, including one on the history of the [[Order of Saint Stanislaus|Order of Saint Stanislaus Bishop and Martyr]] 1765-1795 in the catalogue ''Praemiando Incitat, Order Świętego Stanisława 1765-1831'', Warszawa 2016.
He has set up many thematic exhibitions, e.g., he acted as initiator and co-author of the show ''For the Homeland and the Nation. 300 Years of the [[Order of the White Eagle (Poland)|Order of the White Eagle]]'' at the [[Royal Castle, Warsaw|Warsaw Royal Castle]] in 2005.<ref name=cn>Tadeusz Jeziorowski, ''Ordery napoleońskie. Ordery generałów polskich w epoce napoleońskiej'', Warszawa (cover)</ref>

{{Redirect|The Captain and the Kids|the Elton John album|The Captain & the Kid}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox comic strip |title=The Katzenjammer Kids |image=Katzenjammer1901.jpg | caption=[[Rudolph Dirks]]' ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' (1901) |author= [[Rudolph Dirks]] (creator, 1897–1913)
[[Harold Knerr]] (1914–1949)
[[Doc Winner]] (1949–1956)
[[Joe Musial]] (1956–1977)
Mike Senich (1977–1981)
Angelo DeCesare (1981–1986)
[[Hy Eisman]] (1986–2006) |current = |status=Concluded; in reprints |syndicate=[[King Features Syndicate]] |genre=Humor |first={{start date and age|December 12, 1897}} |last={{end date and age|January 1, 2006}}{{cite web |url=http://comicskingdom.com/celebrate-king-features-100th-anniversary |title=Celebrate King Features' 100th Anniversary! |first=Brian |last=Walker |accessdate=December 10, 2017 |publisher=King Features Syndicate, Inc}} |altnames = ''The Shenanigan Kids'' }} '''''The Katzenjammer Kids''''' is an American [[comic strip]] created by [[Rudolph Dirks]] in 1897, and later drawn by [[Harold Knerr]] for 35 years (1914 to 1949).[http://lambiek.net/artists/d/dirks_r.htm Dirks profile]: "Born in Heide, Germany, Rudolph Dirks moved with his parents to Chicago at the age of seven." It debuted December 12, 1897, in the ''American Humorist'', the Sunday supplement of [[William Randolph Hearst]]'s ''[[New York Journal]]''. Dirks was the first cartoonist to regularly express dialogue in comic characters through the use of [[speech balloons]].{{cite web |url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1989458_1989457_1989441,00.html |title=Top 10 Long-Running Comic Strips / The Katzenjammer Kids |author=Claire Suddath |publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine |date=May 17, 2010 |accessdate=May 17, 2010}} The comic strip was turned into a stage play in 1903. It inspired several animated cartoons and was one of 20 strips included in the [[Comic Strip Classics stamps|Comic Strip Classics]] series of U.S. commemorative postage stamps. After a series of legal battles between 1912 and 1914, Dirks left the Hearst organization and began a new strip, first titled '''''Hans and Fritz''''' and then '''''The Captain and the Kids'''''. It featured the same characters seen in ''The Katzenjammer Kids'', which was continued by Knerr. The two separate versions of the strip competed with each other until 1979, when ''The Captain and the Kids'' ended its six-decade run. ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' published its last strip on January 1, 2006, but is still distributed in reprints by [[King Features Syndicate]], making it the oldest comic strip still in [[print syndication|syndication]] and the longest-running ever. ==History== ===Creation and early years=== [[File:Katzenjammer Kids 1922.jpg|thumb|left|A Sunday comic strip from May 14, 1922, by [[Harold Knerr]]]] ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' was inspired by ''[[Max and Moritz]]'', a children's story of the 1860s by German author [[Wilhelm Busch]]. ''Katzenjammer'' translates literally as ''the wailing of cats'' (i.e. "caterwaul") but is used to mean ''contrition after a failed endeavor'' or ''hangover'' in German (and, in the latter sense, in English too). Whereas Max & Moritz were grotesquely but comically put to death after seven destructive pranks, the Katzenjammer Kids and the other characters still thrive. ===Dirks and Knerr=== {{Infobox comic strip | title = The Captain and the Kids | image = Johndirkscapkids22976.jpg | caption = John Dirks' ''The Captain and the Kids'' (February 29, 1976) | author = [[Rudolph Dirks]] (1914–c. 1955) | current = John Dirks (c. 1955–1979) | status = Concluded mostly [[Sunday strip]] | syndicate = [[World Feature Service]] (1914–1931)
[[United Feature Syndicate]] (1931–1979)Booker, M. Keith. "United Feature Syndicate," in ''Comics through Time: A History of Icons, Idols, and Ideas'' ([[ABC-CLIO]], 2014), p. 399. | publisher = United Feature | genre = Humor | first = {{start date and age|1914}} | last= {{end date and age|1979}} | altnames = ''Hans und Fritz'' }} ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' was so popular that it became two competing comic strips and the subject of a lawsuit. This happened because Dirks, in 1912, wanted to take a break after drawing the strip for 15 years, but the Hearst newspaper syndicate would not allow it. Dirks left anyway, and the strip was taken over by Harold Knerr. Dirks' last strip appeared March 16, 1913.Knoll og Tott – 100 år i Norge (Egmont Serieforlaget, 2011), p. 55. {{ISBN|978-82-429-4437-5}}. Dirks sued, and after a long legal battle, the Hearst papers were allowed to continue ''The Katzenjammer Kids'', with Knerr as writer and artist. He took over permanently in the summer of 1914. However, Dirks was allowed to create an almost identical strip of his own for the rival [[Pulitzer, Inc.|Pulitzer]] newspapers, although he had to use a different name for the strip. Initially named ''Hans und Fritz'' after the two naughty protagonist brothers, Dirks' new feature was called ''The Captain and the Kids'' from 1918 on. ''The Captain and the Kids'' was very similar to ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' in terms of content and characters, but Dirks had a looser and more verbal style than Knerr, who on the other hand often produced stronger, more direct gags and drawings. ''The Captain and the Kids'' soon proved to equal the popularity of ''The Katzenjammer Kids''. It was later distributed by the [[United Feature Syndicate]] (while Hearst's King Features distributed ''The Katzenjammer Kids''). ''The Captain and the Kids'' also introduced some new characters. Ginga Dun is a snooty Indian trader who can outsmart almost anyone and only talks in verse. Captain Bloodshot is a pint-sized pirate rival of [[Long John Silver|John Silver]]'s. ===1950s to the present=== ''The Captain and the Kids'' expanded as a [[daily strip]] during the 1930s, but it had only a short run. However, the [[Sunday strip]] remained popular for decades. From 1946, Dirks' son, John Dirks, gradually began doing more of the work on ''The Captain and the Kids''. They introduced new characters and plots during the 1950s, including a 1958 science fiction storyline about a brilliant inventor and alien invasions. Even as John Dirks took over most of the work, Rudolph Dirks signed the strip until his death in 1968. John Dirks' drawing shifted slightly towards a more square-formed line, though it maintained the original style until ''The Captain and the Kids'' ended its run in 1979.{{cite book |last1=Eckhorst |first1=Tim |title=Rudolph Dirks – Katzenjammer, Kids & Kauderwelsch |year=2012 |publisher=Deich Verlag |location=[[Wewelsfleth]] |language=German |isbn=978-3-942074-05-6 |page=100 }} Knerr continued drawing ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' until his death in 1949; the strip was then written and drawn by [[Doc Winner|Charles H. "Doc" Winner]] (1949–56), with [[Joe Musial]] taking over in 1956. Musial was replaced on ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' by Mike Senich (1976–81), Angelo DeCesare (1981–86), and [[Hy Eisman]] (1986–2006). Now syndicated in reprint form, the strip is distributed internationally to some 50 newspapers and magazines.[http://cartoonician.com/getting-hy-on-comics-a-profile-of-hy-eisman/ ''A Profile of Hy Eisman'', Hogan's Alley #15] Eisman reused a lot of old gags and stories in later years. == Characters and story == ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' (three brothers in the first strip but soon reduced to two) featured Hans and Fritz, twins who rebelled against authority, particularly in the form of their mother, Mama; der Captain, a shipwrecked sailor who acted as a surrogate father; and der Inspector, an official from the school system. Other characters included John Silver, a pirate sea captain and his crew, and King Bongo, a primitive-living but sophisticated-acting [[Black people|black]] jungle monarch who ruled a tropical island. Several of the characters spoke in stereotypical German-accented English. The main plot of the strip was Hans and Fritz would pull a prank or trick on one of the adults which resulted in their being hunted down and given a spanking in the end panel. Knerr's version of ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' introduced several major new characters in the 1930s. Miss Twiddle, a pompous tutor, and her brainy niece Lena came to stay permanently with the Katzenjammers in early 1936. Later in the year Twiddle's ex-pupil, "boy prodigy" Rollo Rhubarb joined them. The ever-smug Rollo is always trying to outwit Hans and Fritz, but his cunning plans often backfire. Notable features of the later strips included a more constructive relationship between the Captain and the boys, who sometimes had friendly conversations instead of fights. The King and his people were now Polynesian rather than African. == In other media == === ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' === [[File:Policy and Pie part 1 of 2 (1918).webm|thumb|''Policy and Pie'' (''The Katzenjammer Kids'') part 1 of 2 (1918)]] [[File:Policy and Pie part 2 of 2 (1918).webm|thumb|''Policy and Pie'' (''The Katzenjammer Kids'') part 2 of 2 (1918)]] The ''Katzenjammer Kids'' characters initially appeared outside comics in a handful of live-action silent films, the first released in 1898. This first film, titled ''The Katzenjammer Kids In School'' was made for the [[Biograph Company]] by [[William George Bitzer]]. This film was followed in 1900 by another Bitzer-Biograph film, ''The Katzenjammer Kids in Love.''{{cite journal|auhtorlink1=Maurice Horn|last=Horn|first=Maurice|title=Comics and Cinema: The Beginnings (1896–1913)|journal=International Journal of Comic Art|date=15 October 2007|volume=9|issue=2|pages=60}} Between December 1916 and August 1918, a total of 37 ''Katzenjammer Kids'' silent cartoon shorts were produced by William Randolph Hearst's own cartoon studio [[International Film Service]], which adapted well-known comic strips owned by Hearst for animation. The series was retired in 1918 at the height of the characters' popularity – partly because of the growing tension against titles with German associations after World War I. The comic strip was briefly renamed to ''The Shenanigan Kids'' around this time, and in 1920 another five cartoons were produced under this title. All ''Katzenjammer Kids''/''Shenanigan Kids'' cartoons from International Film Services were directed (and most likely also animated) by [[Gregory La Cava]]. In addition, the Katzenjammer Kids had appearances (along with a lot of other King Features comic strip stars) in Filmation's TV special ''[[Popeye Meets the Man Who Hated Laughter]]'' (1972). === ''The Captain and the Kids'' === [[Image:Captainandthekids.jpg|thumb|right|The title card for ''The Captain and the Kids''.]] In 1938, ''The Captain and the Kids'' became the subject of [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]'s first self-produced series of theatrical [[short subject]] cartoons, directed by [[William Hanna]], Bob Allen and [[Friz Freleng]]: ''[[The Captain and the Kids (MGM animated series)|The Captain and the Kids]]''. Unlike the strip, which focused most of all on the gruesomely amusing antics of Hans and Fritz, the MGM cartoons often centered on the Captain. The series was overall unsuccessful, ending after one year and a total of 15 cartoons. Following that cancellation, Freleng returned to [[Warner Bros.]], where he had earlier been an animation director. The Captain was voiced by [[Billy Bletcher]], and John Silver was voiced by [[Mel Blanc]]. ''The Captain and the Kids'' version of the strip was also animated for television as a back-up segment on [[Filmation]]'s ''[[Archie's TV Funnies]]'' in 1971. ==Cultural legacy== * In July 2009 a street in [[Heide]], Germany (where Dirks was born) was named after the cartoonist.{{cite book |last1=Eckhorst |first1=Tim |title=Rudolph Dirks – Katzenjammer, Kids & Kauderwelsch |year=2012 |publisher=Deich Verlag |location=[[Wewelsfleth]] |language=German |isbn=978-3-942074-05-6 |page=107 }} === ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' === *''The Katzenjammer Kids'' are still very popular in the Scandinavian countries Denmark and Norway (where they are known as ''Knoll og Tott''); in both countries, an annual comic book has been published almost every Christmas since 1911 (the only exceptions reportedly being the years 1913 and 1944). For the most part, Harold Knerr's version of the comic is used in these annual comic books. In [[Sweden]], the annual Katzenjammer Kids comic book was also a tradition for many years, from 1928–1977.{{cite web |url=http://www.seriesam.com/cgi-bin/guide?s=knoll+och+tott |title=Knoll och Tott |trans-title=Knoll and Tott |language=German |accessdate=December 10, 2017 |publisher=Seriesam AB}} *[[Art Clokey]], the creator of [[Gumby]], has claimed that ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' inspired the creation of Gumby's nemeses, [[Block-heads (Gumby)|The Block-heads]].{{Cite web|last=gumbyworld.com|title=The Blockheads|url=http://www.gumbyworld.com/memorylane/histblkhd.htm}} *''[[Playboy]]'' frequently featured in its late 1970s-early 1980s "Playboy Funnies" pages a spoof of ''The Katzenjammer Kids'' called ''The Krautzenbummer Kids'' with adult style gags. *French [[dark cabaret]] band [[Katzenjammer Kabarett]] is thus named in a homage to the strip, as is the Norwegian symphonic pop/swing group ''[[Katzenjammer (band)|Katzenjammer]]''. === ''The Captain and the Kids'' === *''The Captain and the Kids'' has been published as an annual comic book in Norway since 1987. When no more reproducible material was available in 2001, Per Sanderhage, the editor of the Danish comic strip agency PIB, negotiated a deal where ''[[Ferd'nand]]'' cartoonist Henrik Rehr would redraw 32 pages loosely based on old magazine clippings for the annual. In spite of the artistic/ethical questions this raises regarding the testament of Dirks' original work, the arrangement continues on to this day. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|United States|Comics}} *[http://kingfeatures.com/comics/comics-a-z/?id=Katzenjammer_Kids King Features] *[http://www.toonopedia.com/katzen.htm The Katzenjammer Kids] at [[Don Markstein's Toonopedia]]. [https://www.webcitation.org/6bQLWbDWA Archived] from the original on September 9, 2015. *[http://www.toonopedia.com/cap_kids.htm The Captain and the Kids] at Don Markstein's Toonopedia. [https://www.webcitation.org/66nyhBfiD Archived] from the original on April 9, 2012. {{King Features Syndicate Comics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Katzenjammer Kids}} [[Category:American comic strips]] [[Category:1890s comics]] [[Category:Comic strips started in the 1890s]] [[Category:2006 comics endings]] [[Category:Gag-a-day comics]] [[Category:Child characters in comics]] [[Category:Male characters in comics]] [[Category:Fictional German people]] [[Category:Fictional American people of German descent]] [[Category:Fictional twins]] [[Category:Fictional tricksters]] [[Category:Comic strip duos]] [[Category:Animated duos]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:American comics adapted into films]] [[Category:Comics adapted into animated series]] [[Category:Comics adapted into plays]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1897]] [[Category:1897 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer animated short films]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Tracy Posner | image = | caption = | birth_place = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1962}} | occupation = Actress, animal rights rescuer, activist | yearsactive = 1991–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Burt Ward]]|1990}} | children = 1 | parents = Sari Posner
[[Victor Posner]] | relatives = [[Steven Posner]] (paternal half-brother) }} '''Tracy Posner Ward''' (born 1962) is an actress, [[animal rights]] rescuer and activist, with her husband, actor [[Burt Ward]]. She is a daughter of the late American businessman and philanthropist [[Victor Posner]] and his second wife Sari Posner. In 1983, she was appointed as a vice president, assistant treasurer and assistant secretary to several corporations to include [[Wilson Brothers & Company|Wilson Brothers]], [[NVF company]], [[Southeastern Public Service Authority]] and Birdsboro Corporation.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nLkmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cwIGAAAAIBAJ&pg=2584,3046519&dq=tracy+posner&hl=en|title=People In Business|date=December 26, 1983|work=[[Google News Archive]]|publisher=[[The Miami News]]|accessdate=26 July 2010}} In 1993, while still active in her father's many companies, Posner Ward was described as "one of the world's wealthiest women".{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,307170,00.html|title=BATMAN RETURNS|date=July 9, 1993|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=ew.com|accessdate=26 July 2010}} ==Animal rights work== In 1994, Tracy Posner Ward and her husband, actor Burt Ward, founded Gentle Giants Rescue and Adoptions,{{cite web|url=http://www.gentlegiantsrescue.com/ |title=Gentle Giants Rescue and Adoptions |publisher=Gentlegiantsrescue.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-11}} a giant-breed dog rescue organization.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20131390,00.html|title=Canine Crusader|date=May 29, 2000|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|publisher=people.com|accessdate=26 July 2010}} The Wards operate a communal home for dogs, where they nurse 45–50 dogs at a time back to health, then put them up for adoption at their home and facility in [[Norco, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gentlegiantinfoandnews.com/ |title=Gentle Giant Info and News |publisher=Gentle Giant Info and News |date= |accessdate=2010-07-11}}{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/news-articles/inland-valley-daily-bulletin/mi_8075/is_20100410/gentle-giants-rescue-adoptions-launches/ai_n53107220/ |title=Gentle Giants Rescue and Adoptions launches dog food brand | Inland Valley Daily Bulletin Newspaper | Find Articles at BNET |publisher=Findarticles.com |date=2010-04-10 |accessdate=2010-07-11}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}{{cite web |url=http://www.presstelegram.com/ci_14865846 |title=Ex-'Batman' star creates line of dog food |publisher=Press-Telegram |date= |accessdate=2010-07-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100514155719/http://www.presstelegram.com/ci_14865846 |archive-date=2010-05-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The city of [[Norco, California|Norco]] limits nonprofit animal rescue organizations to 55 animals on premises at a time.{{cite web|last1=Norco|first1=California|title=Requirements for animal licensing|url=http://www.norco.ca.us/depts/parks/animals/default.asp|website=Norco City Government|publisher=City of Norco, California|accessdate=21 June 2016}} ==Business career== In August 1984, Posner Ward represented her father, [[Victor Posner]], who was unable to attend the renaming of a street in his name by [[Hermitage, Pennsylvania]].{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4ZImAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bAEGAAAAIBAJ&pg=3897,2092868&dq=tracy+posner&hl=en|title=Posner Gets A Boulevard In Hermitage|date=August 23, 1984|work=[[Google News Archive]]|publisher=[[The Miami News]]|accessdate=26 July 2010}} Speaking to the assembled guests and reporters, Posner Ward apologized for her father's inability to attend by saying, "My father planned to come up to the last minute; I hope you realize how hard he tried to make it. He is truly honored by this decision." She declined to speak about her father's legal case in Florida. In 1989, Victor Posner sent Tracy to take over Burt Ward's publicly traded fund-raising company.{{cite news|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/SHOWBIZ/TV/09/17/people.watn.ward/|title=Former Caped Crusader owns visual effects company|date=September 17, 2002|work=[[CNN]]|publisher=cnn.com|accessdate=26 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080507230306/http://archives.cnn.com/2002/SHOWBIZ/TV/09/17/people.watn.ward/|archivedate=7 May 2008|df=}} In 1994, Posner Ward sued her half brother [[Steven Posner]], claiming he let one of her smaller [[trust fund]]s, worth $2 million, dwindle to $100,000 with undocumented loans and other transactions of little or no value.{{cite web|url=http://www.3dca.flcourts.org/opinions/3d03-2989.pdf |title=Microsoft Word - 3D03-2989.3op..doc |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-07-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.familyfight.com/media/miami_herald_020414b.htm |title=Planning To Avoid It |publisher=The Family Fight |date= |accessdate=2010-07-11}}{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UOwNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=C3ADAAAAIBAJ&pg=2534,3602363&dq=tracy+posner&hl=en|title=Posner Siblings in Trust Dispute|date=July 23, 1994|work=[[Google News Archive]]|publisher=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|accessdate=26 July 2010}} In the lawsuit initiated by Tracy Ward,{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-07-25/business/fi-19617_1_victor-posner|title=Other News|date=July 25, 1994|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=latimes.com|accessdate=26 July 2010}} she alleged in [[Eleventh Judicial Circuit Court of Florida|Dade Circuit Court]] that the trust should have passed to her at age 21 and kept secret until 1993. Posner Ward was involved in lawsuits until April 2015 which entangled the estate of her late father, industrialist [[Victor Posner]], who changed his will shortly before he died in 2002, and removed his children and grandchildren as heirs to his estate. A lawsuit by Troy Posner, not including Tracy, was eventually settled for $14 million.{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4183/is_20031020/ai_n10058231/|title=Baltimore lawyers reach $14M settlement in Victor Posner's contested|date=October 20, 2003|work=[[FindArticles]]|publisher=[[Daily Record (Maryland)]]|accessdate=26 July 2010 | first=Alisa | last=Bralove}} ==Acting== Posner appeared in three films with her husband, Burt Ward. She also appeared in a small role in the 2001 film ''[[What's the Worst That Could Happen?]]''{{cite news|url=http://movies.nytimes.com/person/1100418/Tracy-Posner-Ward|title=Tracy Posner Ward|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=26 July 2010}} ==Personal life== Tracy is the wife of actor Burt Ward,{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Russell Scott|title=Canine Crusader|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20131390,00.html|publisher=People magazine|accessdate=11 July 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nndb.com/people/735/000024663/ |title=Burt Ward |publisher=Nndb.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-11}} who played [[Robin (comics)|Robin]] opposite [[Adam West]] in the ''[[Batman (TV series)|Batman]]'' television series (1966–68). The Wards have a daughter, Melody. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.gentlegiantsrescue.com/ Gentle Giants Rescue and Adoptions website] * {{IMDb name|0692735}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091129035040/http://shefaro.com/holyborzoibatman/ Holy Borzoi Batman!] Tracy and Burt Ward Gentle Giants Dog Photos * [http://www.1stopfordogs.com/mastiff-dog-rescue-clubs.htm List of United States and Canadian Mastiff Dog Rescue Clubs] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100821125725/http://www.animalnetwork.org/ANIMAL_NETWORK/Rescue_Directory/DogRescueOrganizations_SouthernCA.htm List of Canine Rescue Organizations in Southern California] {{DEFAULTSORT:Posner, Tracy}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Keepers of animal sanctuaries]] [[Category:1961 births]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Tuviah Friedman | image = | alt = | caption = Tuviah Friedman in Polish [[Internal Security Corps]] uniform between 1945 and 1946 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1922|01|23|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Radom, Poland]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|01|13|1922|01|23|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Haifa, Israel]] | nationality = Israeli | other_names = | known_for = helped to capture Eichmann | occupation = [[Nazi hunter]] }} __NOTOC__ '''Tuviah Friedman''' (23 January 1922 – 13 January 2011<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.walla.co.il/?w=/22/1780032|script-title=he:טוביה פרידמן, ממסייעי לכידת אייכמן, הלך לעולמו|trans-title=Tuviah Friedman, who helped to capture Eichmann, dies|last=Mandel|first=Kobi|date=13 January 2011|publisher=[[Walla!]]|language=Hebrew|accessdate=13 January 2011}}</ref><ref name=JPOST>{{cite news| url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=203616| title=Nazi hunter Tuvya Friedman laid to rest in Haifa| work=[[Jerusalem Post]]| date=January 14, 2011| accessdate=24 January 2011}}</ref>) was a [[Nazi hunter]] and director of the Institute for the Documentation of [[Nazism|Nazi]] [[War Crimes]] in [[Haifa, Israel]].
Friedman was born in [[Radom]], Poland, in 1922. During World War II he was imprisoned in a [[Nazi concentration camp]] near Radom, from which he escaped in 1944. The following year he was appointed an interrogation officer in the [[Gdańsk]] jail. From 1946 to 1952 he worked for [[Haganah]] Wien in [[Austria]], as Director of Staff of the Documentation Center in [[Vienna]], where he and his colleagues hunted down numerous Nazis.<ref> [https://www.academia.edu/2905417/_Praktische_Geschichte_Der_Beitrag_judischer_Organisationen_zur_Verfolgung_von_NS-Verbrechern_in_Polen_und_Osterreich_in_den_spaten_40er_Jahren Stephan Stach: »Praktische Geschichte«, Der Beitrag jüdischer Organisationen zur Verfolgung von NS-Verbrechern in Polen und Österreich in den späten 40er Jahren, in: Fritz Bauer Institut (Hg.), Katharina Stengel (Hg.), Opfer als Akteure, Interventionen ehemaliger NS-Verfolgter in der Nachkriegszeit, Frankfurt (Main) 2008, 242-262.]</ref> Afterwards, in [[Israel]], he played a role in the [[capture of Adolf Eichmann]].<ref name=JPOST />
==Papers== Friedman's autobiography is titled ''The Hunter''. The archives at [[Yad Vashem]] in Israel contain dossiers on various Nazis, collected by Friedman.<ref>{{cite book | last = Levy | first = Alan | authorlink = Alan Levy | title = Nazi Hunter: The Wiesenthal File | edition = Revised 2002 | year = 2006 | origyear = 1993 | publisher = Constable & Robinson | location = London | isbn = 978-1-84119-607-7 | page=139 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Serge and Beate Klarsfeld]] * [[Yaron Svoray]] * [[Elliot Welles]] * [[Simon Wiesenthal]] * [[Efraim Zuroff]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://yivoarchives.org/index.php?p=collections/controlcard&id=33560 Guide to the Papers of Tuviah Friedman (RG 1196)], YIVO Institute for Jewish Research *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070929083346/http://motlc.specialcol.wiesenthal.com/instdoc/d08c07/rol1z1.html ''My Role in Operation Eichmann''] by Tuviah Friedman. Institute of Documentation in Israel for the Investigation of Nazi War Crimes: Haifa. * Korrespondenz Lothar Hermann Coronel Suarez Argentinien Ergreifung Adolf Eichmann, Special Collection 8 <!-- pls. Wikify --> * Tuviah Friedman Korrespondenz to Simon Wiesenthal, Germany National Bibliothek <!-- pls. Wikify -->
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Friedman, Tuviah}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Nazi hunters]] [[Category:Holocaust survivors]] [[Category:Polish Jews]] [[Category:Israeli Jews]] [[Category:Polish emigrants to Israel]]
